comments: Conducted inspection today with Ted Schwinabart and Jeff Snyder with the Bureau of Mines.  No activity at the mine today as the men are all at MSHA training.  Mining and backfilling has continued on the elklick on INC II. Preparing to shoot on the Harlem on INC IV.  No activity on the Lower Bakerstown.  Advised operator to continue backfilling as the Bureau would like to see at least 40 acres backfilled by the end of the year or more bond may be requested.  Note, as the weather allows, continue to maintenance all drainage structures in preparation for spring flows, repair any rills and maintain or install permiter markers as needed.

Contractor is working on the deep mine face-up area.  The sediment and drainage controls are being completed as the site progresses. Pond #3 was not discharging. The discharge point for this structure needs to be re-established so that it can be monitored and sampled properly. Quarterly BOM water monitoring reports and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  The newly constructed Pond #3 needs to be treated for suspended solids in order to compliant with discharge limits when discharging.

Inspection of the site with Tom Murray.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. The ponds were not discharging. Quarter BOM water monitoring reports and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  No blasting has occurred during this quarter of mining activities.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.

The Operator has submitted a request for temporary cessation of mining activities at this site to be approved.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. Ponds were not discharging.  The Operator is working on backfilling operations.  No problems were observed during this inspection.
Deep mining on one section today.  Processing coal and loading trucks for shipment.  Pond #1 was not discharging.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.

Actively mining the Sewickly coal seams today.  Processing coal and loading trucks for shipment.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. Ponds were not discharging on this date. Quarterly BOM water monitoring reports and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  Blasting records are on file at the mine office with no violations noted.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.
No changes in permit conditions since my last inspection.  Ponds were not discharging.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.
No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.  Pond and traps were not discharging.

Actively mining the the #2 Franklin coal seam on this date.  Sediment and drainge controls were functioning properly today. Pond #4 was not discharging. Quarterly BOM water monitoring reports and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  Blasting records are being kept on site with no violations noted.

No activity on this site today.  The haulroad has washed due to a large storm event and still needs repaired.  When Tri-Star Mining is finished backfilling and reclamation on the Franklin pit area, G&S coal is to continue with backfilling operations and reclamation until the entire site is completed.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. Pond #3 was not discharging. Quarterly BOM water monitoring reports and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.
No changes in permit conditons since my last inspection.  There are some bare areas that need to be repaired.
No changes in permit conditons since my last inspection  Pond was not discharging.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.

Inspection today with the LRC and BOM staff to review the new Bakerstown ammendment. The LRC voted to approve this ammendment.       Mining on the Harlem seam today. Discharge today from pond #2  as follows:  pH 7.1, 386 Us at 40 degrees F.  Discharge from pond #3 has  pH 7.3, 224 Us, at 42 degrees F.  Pond #1 has a 6.2 pH , 1592 Us, at 41 degrees F.
This permit is in the final stage of bond release.  Little change on site since last inspection.  No problems observed.

. No discharge today.  Little change since last inpection.   Reveg on the highwall slope looks good.

Office review of a Citizen's Complaint filed with the Bureau on 10-20-17 in regards to the site lighting at the Casselman Mine.  The Bureau has received complaints in the past on the site lighting at the DM-09-113 Casselman Deep Mine. At that time, the operator manually adjusted the mine site lighting away from the Amish Road area to the best of their ability. The limits of adjustment were established by illumination requirements set by MSHA.  No further actions on this issue will be taken by the Bureau.  The operator is not required to make any changes in regards to site illumination.   Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Inspection today with Mark Carney present to review site for bond release.  There are 22 acres of phase 2, as per Planting Reports # 1 & 2, and 56 acres of phase 3, as per Planting Reports #'s 1,2, and 3, which meet Permit requirements for bond release.

Onsite review today with John Shannon, Superintendant for Walker Brothers Mining, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The site is active today with mining operations in progress on the Red Stone and Big Vein Coal Seams. Coal is being blended and stockpiled.  No discharges are noted at any of the three ponds today. Lime is placed in the ditches to Ponds 1 and 2 to pre-treat water entering the ponds.  No Issues Noted  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

The seep was not flowing on this date.  Drainage and sediment controls are functioning properly. Pond #1 was discharging a 7.8 ph, 1116 specific conductance @ 57 degrees F...   Please note that backfilling equipment is to be returned to this permit site by November 15, 2017 and backfilling is to resume until the site is totally backfilled and reclaimed.  If you have any questions please contact this inspector.

There was no activity at this site during this inspection.  Sediment and drainage controls are functioning properly. Pond #1 was not discharging. NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  No changes or environmental concerns were observed during this inspection.
No discharge today.  DMR's are current and appear in good order.   Mining and backfilling in progress. Renew your blasting adv. if you have not done so already.
No discharge today. Pond levels are very low or dry. No problems observed.  Renew your insurance if you have not already done so.

Onsite review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The mine is in Inactive Status.  Discussed the Draw Down Well and associated pipe installation with Aaron Miller. The rising mine pool elevation will drive the schedule for future work at the site. Mettiki is planning on completing this work throughout the fall of this year.  The current Mine Pool Elevation is 8' below the elevation that requires pump and pipe installation.  No changes on the site. Pond is discharging.  No issues noted.   Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Mining on the Redstone coal seam today.  Coal is being processed and loaded for shipment.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. The ponds were not discharging. Quarterly BOM water monitoring and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  Pond material is being dumped on site from MER as per the approved permit. No problems from the dump site were observed.  The most recent blasting report was review with no violations being noted.  No environmental problems were observed during this inspection.

On site review today with Dewight Kriezer and Aaron Miller for the purposes of inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Remediation work is underway at the seep areas located between Ponds 1 and 8. The operator will be working at and possibly over the Permitted Acreage at the seep remediation area. If the operator needs to work outside the permitted area, the operator will notify this inspector and will submit an Incidental Boundary Revision along with "As-Built" drawings of the area upon completion of remediation work. All work for seep remediation will be performed on Mettiki Coal property.  Coal is stockpiled and is being trucked and trained off of the site.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344

This was a Bond Release Inspection conducted with BOM Revegetation Specialist Mark Carney and Vindex Energy employees Rodney Tichinel, Terry Nair and Nick Riggins.  The bond release was for Phase I, II and III for 4 acres of haulroad. The area does meet the standards and was approved for release on this date.
No discharge today. Pond level is low. DMR,s are current and appear in good order. This site is revegetated except for the refuse pit. No problems observed.
No discharge today, ponds are empty. DMR,s are current and appear in good order. Little change from last inspection.

This was a Bond Release inspection conducted with BOM Revegetation Specialist Mark Carney and Tri-Star Mining General Mine Foreman Ray Tighe.  Tri -Star Mining has submitted an application for Phase III Bond Releas of Planting report #8 containing 6 acres. This area was inspected on this date and meets the standards for revegetation success and was approved on this date.

On site review of the permit area today with Mr. Mark Beachy, Land Owner, Ray Tighe, Mine Superintendant, Mark Carney and Ralph Mongold, Bureau of Mines, for the purpose of Phase III Bond Release and for inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The Permit is active today. Mining is in progress on the Little Pittsburgh Coal Seam. Coal is stockpiled and blending is in progress, coal is being trucked off site. Roads are being watered today.  Ditch and sump maintenance has been completed at several locations throughout the permit. Rill and wash repair is scheduled for the coming weeks.  There are two Planting Reports up for Phase III Bond Release review today. Planting Report #6 has 12 acres; Planting Report #25 has 6 acres. Both of the Planting Reports are on the Beachy Tract. Land Owner, Mark Beachy was present for the Bond Release review. After the reviews, I asked Mr. Beachy if he had any objections to either of the areas being released. He replied that he had "no objections, the areas look great".  Mr. Beachy asked about removal of the haul road that goes through his property, I told him that the haul road will be narrowed up in the coming weeks, but will need to remain open for vegetation inspections, equipment transport for any additional reclamation and repairs, rill repairs and Bond Release Inspections. Mr. Beachy was frustrated when I told him that the haul road needed to be kept open for the five year Bond Release time period.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301) 697-0344

This deep mine site was actively mining coal on one section today.  Coal was being processed and loaded onto trucks for shipment.  Drainage and sediment controls are functioning properly. Pond #1 was not discharging. Pond #2 was not discharging. Quarterly BOM water monitoring and NetDMR's are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  The haulroad is being watered and was in satisfactory condition.  No problems were observed during this inspection.

No problems were observed during this inspection.

The operator will repair any and all rills and washes on Refuse 2.  The operator will schedule and complete the reclamation, rill repair, low area fills, seeding and mulching by the end of December 31, 2017. Trees and grasses look good and all areas meet the standards for revegetation success for Phase II Bond Release.  Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. Quarterly BOM water monitoring and NetDMR reporting is up to date and no violations were noted.  The following drainage control removal and/or breachment are approved and work can begin:  Ponds or Traps associated with NPDES MD0066541; Outfall 001 (Trap #2) - This structure can be removed. (Part of this structure should remain as an interior road sump.) Ditch #2 is to be reclaimed up to Trap #4.  Outfall 002 (Trap #7) - This structure is to remain as part of Mr. Ayres water supply replacement system.  Outfall 003 (Trap #5) - This structure is to be breached for "Wildlife Habitat Enhancement" and Ditch #5 is to remain.    Ponds or Traps associated with NPDES MDG852427; Outfall 004 (Pond A) - This structure is to be removed and reclaimed.  Outfall 010 (Trap #10) - This structure is to be removed and reclaimed.  Trap #1 (not an outfall) - This structure is to be breached for "Wildlife Habitat Enhancement" and the associated ditch is to remain.  Inline Trap #4 (not an outfall) - This structure is to be breached for "Wildlife Habitat Enhancement". and Ditch #4 is to remain.   If you have any questions please contact me.

Onsite review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The permit has been revoked. The bond has been forfeited.  A large area, approximately 15' wide by 20' high, has slid off of the breast. The slide goes from the base of the breast to the top of the breast on Pond 2. The emergency spillway will be lowered to decrease the water level in the discharging cell. Work will be performed under an AML Maintenance Contract.  While the AML Contractor is on site, ditch maintenance at Pond 1 will be performed.  Pond 2 is discharging, pH-7.3, Specific Conductance-679. Pond 1 is not discharging.    Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

This site is revegetated and in the late stages of bond release [phase  3]. Inspection today with Mark Carney and John Carey present to review 5 acres of phase one, and 17 acres of phase two and three [as per Planting Reports 1 & 2].   These areas meet Permit requirements for bond release.

This Permit is in the final stages of bond release.  Reveg on site is in good condition.  Inspection today to review 3 acres eligible for phase 3 bond release as per Planting Report #21. This area meets Permit requirements for bond release.

Installation of the stone liner in the drainway in increment 3 is scheduled as soon as critical areas in increment 4 are completed for this fall.

No discharge today.  Tom Murray present to inspect reveg repairs and reveg condition in general.  The northern half of the reveg looks good with only two spots or so that need repair. The southern section towards pond #8, should be topdressed in the spring.

Onsite review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The mine is active today. Rejects are being trucked off the site. This inspection was conducted on 9/19/2017, from a complaint last evening by phone to this inspector.  On site today was Al Hooker, Chief of Permitting, Mark Hajas of the Permitting Section, Randy Sharpless (Property owner's father) Tim Schwinabart the Operator for G & S Coal Company.  The complaint last evening was that the property owner, Harland Sharpless, did not have any water in the well.  Randy had dropped a pebble in the well and according to him it hit the bottom of the well and it was dry. The Operator had Brenneman Well drilling at the site prior to our arrival.  They took water depths of the well and it was within similar depth when the well was drilled.  According to the records and the well cap when the well was drilled it produced 7 gpm of flow. After discussing the situation we decided to do a recovery test.  After completing the recovery test we discovered the well was only producing a half of gpm or less. Al and this inspector reviewed the permit area and Al took gps reading of the auger area and the approximate location of the last blast that was conducted on the site.  On September 22, after reviewing the complaint and permit review, Al Hooker, Chief of Permitting has determined that this mine site has reduced the recovery of this well and G & S Coal Company is to have the well drilled deeper, replace with a new well or a water source. This inspector will contact Tim Schwinabart by telephone and have him to provide a plan to Al Hooker by September 26, 2017 to include: 1) To construct by deepening the existing well, drill a new well or a water source to the resident. 2) The Operator has supplied drinking water to the residence, but with the understanding that if the well goes dry prior to the new or deepened well the Operator will supply the residence with a sanitized water buffalo. If the Operator has any questions or feels the need to dispute the decision of the Bureau of Mines, contact Al Hooker at 301-689-1446 prior to September 26, 2017, the deadline for a plan.

On site review today with Ralph Mongold and Ray Tighe, Mine Superintendant for Tri-Star Mining, to address an anonymous complaint.  A complaint, including pictures of a muddy stream, was text to my State phone on the night of 8- 17-17. I asked the complainant to call me with any information of the impacted stream. I received a call early on 8-18-17. The pictures were of Butcher Run above Barton MD. The stream was extremely turbid and muddy. After an investigation, the source of the turbid water was evident to be Tri-Star Mining's Caledonia Hill Mine, SM-91-419. Samples and pictures were taken of Butcher Run and at the permit boundary where the muddy water was leaving the site.  Tri-Star Mining was directed to construct a ditch to divert the flow of the turbid water to Trap 10. Work on the ditch was initiated immediately. Tri-Star was also directed to clean the last cell of trap 10.  A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued.  Please notify this inspector when all work is complete.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301) 697-0344

On site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Rill repair is required on the Benard Tract. The operator will need to schedule repairs. Repairs will be completed by September 29, 2017  COMAR 26.20.28.06     Regrading or Stabilizing Rills and Gullies.  When rills or gullies are deeper than 9 inches form in areas that have been regraded and top- soiled, the rills and gullies shall be filled, graded or otherwise stabilized and the area reseeded or replanted in accordance with the revegetation requirements. The Bureau shall specify that rills or gullies of lesser size be stabilized and the area reseeded or replanted if the rills or gullies are disruptive to the approved postmining land use or may result in additional erosion and sedimentation.  Please contact this inspector when repairs are completed.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Office review today with Al Hooker and Ralph Mongold for the purpose of inspections and enforcement the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Field inspections at the Refuse 2 area have revealed several seeps of acidic and ferruginous water just off the permit boundary, adjacent to Dutch Run. Three seeps have been identified and water samples have been taken. The Bureau of Mines has identified the seeps, studied the sampling data and reviewed information that has been submitted by Mettiki Coal LLC.  The Bureau has come to the determination that the chemistry of the water from the seeps is similar to the chemistry of the Refuse 2 water. Therefore, the Bureau's decision is that the seeps are directly linked to the Refuse 2 Area Operations.  A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued.

This Field Inspection Report is to address Mettiki Coal LLC's request for an Enforcement Conference and an extension for the compliance deadlines in regards to Notice of Violation and Order 101-170815-NOV.  A letter from Aaron Miller, dated 8/16/2017, states that Mettiki Coal LLC is requesting an Enforcement Conference in regards to Notice of Violation and Order 101-170815-NOV.  In the same letter, Mettiki Coal LLC is requesting that the compliance deadlines set forth in the Notice of Violation and Order be extended.  This inspector will file the request for an Enforcement Conference with the Director of the Bureau of Mines. The Director will set a date for the Enforcement Conference and notify Mettiki Coal LLC of that date.  Mettiki Coal LLC's request for an extension of the compliance deadlines is hereby granted. Mettiki Coal LLC will submit all required plans and schedules for remediation work and water monitoring to the Bureau at the above referenced Enforcement Conference.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344

On site review today with Eddie Smith for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The site is active today. Caustic is in use to treat water. Vindex Energy will provide, to the Bureau, "As-Built" drawings of the entire wetlands/treatment system and a map of all re-disturbed areas throughout the permit. On this date I received a blasting complaint from Randy Slayton, 12905 Vale Summit Rd., Frostburg, MD.  He was complaining that his sewer line was broke and said it probably happened back in January of this year.  He requested that I come and look at his broken sewer line and take pictures. Before going to his residence, Jeff Snyder and I reviewed the blasting records for January, 2017 and found them all to be in compliance with State and Federal laws.  Jeff Snyder, Ron Schartiger and I went to his residence and took pictures of the broken sewer line. The sewer line was cast iron and very rusty and was believed to have been installed in 1974 when the house was built. As we discussed with him, it appeared that the line broke due to the ground settling.  Mr. Slayton did no agree with my findings and requested to speak to the Mine Operator, Jody Ritchie about this problem.  I contacted Jody Ritchie and told him about the complaint and told him that our initial thoughts of the investigation were that the sewer line broke due to the ground settling and not due to blasting activities. Jody requested Mr. Slayton's phone number so that he could talk to him.   No further investigation on this complaint at this time.

After the timber was removed just north of the Pond #3 location, a spring was discovered by the Contract Operator. I was contacted and went to the site to investigate and document the spring.  While on site I contacted my supervisor Tom Murray for advice.  He and the BOM Director John Carey and Jeff Snyder with the BOM Permitting section came to the site to observe and discuss what to do with the spring. Mr. Carey directed me to take water samples & photographs of the spring and document it on this inspection report. We then instructed the Contract Operator James Clark to capture the spring and pipe it off site with a 6" PVC pipe. This spring is to be labeled as "SP-1" and is considered to be a pre existing spring. It is to be added to the required quarterly monitoring sites for this permit.  Kevin Clark, with ARJ, was contacted and made aware of the spring and the required new ground water monitoring site.  As per my last inspection report, ARJ needs to install the required Permit ID sign.

Office review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  A review of the Discharge Monitoring Reports (DMR's) for SM-11-457, NPDES Permit MDG859630, 11-CM-9630 was conducted today.  The January, 2017 DMR showed a violation on the monthly average of Manganese. The recorded monthly average was 3.7; the NPDES Permit monthly average for Manganese is 2.  The February, 2017 DMR showed a violation for the monthly average of Manganese. The recorded monthly average was 2.3; the NPDES Permit monthly average for Manganese is 2. The pH was recorded at 10.3, the daily maximum as per the NPDES Permit is 9.  The March, 2017 DMR showed a violation on pH limits. The pH was recorded at 10.6, the daily maximum as per the NPDES Permit is 9.  The operator was late on submitting complete DMR's for NPDES Permit MDG859630 for the first quarter of 2017. DMR submittal was due on April 28, 2017. Complete DMR submittal was not submitted until May 5, 2017.  The operator was required to inform the Bureau, within 24 hours, if the permitee does not comply with any of the effluent limitations within the NPDES Permit. Please see page 22-23 Section E. Noncompliance with Discharge Limits.  A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued. .

On 3/28/2017 a blasting complaint from Jackie Palaisa, who lives at 19200 James Forest Dr., Frostburg, MD, was received by Jeff Snyder. Miss Palaisa claims that her counter top is cracked and that there is a major crack in the foundation. Also she has hired a contractor to paint and repair the interior drywall and to treat and seal the wood surfaces.  On this date Mike Garner with the MD Bureau of Mines/AML Section, Jeff Snyder and I visited the residence to investigate her claims. We could not find any major cracks in the foundation. The cracks in the countertop and drywall appear to be form normal effects of settling.  All blasting records are kept on file at the mine office and no violations were noted. Current blasting operations are approximately 3,540 feet from the residence.  Jeff has been speaking to Miss Palaisa and she has requested another pre-blast be done when all the remodeling work is completed.  No further investigation per this complaint is needed at this time.

This was an OSM Independent Inspection conducted by OSM Inspector Stefanie Miller and I.   The Operator did have a dozer on site working on the backfill.  Seep-1 was flowing approximately 15gpm. The seep field tested a 4.5 ph and +10 iron with a HACH kit. The operator has been treating the seep with liquid caustic. This past weekend the valve was opened and the caustic tank was drained by someone or something, possibly deer. I instructed the Permittee to install a valve with a locking device so that this doesn't occur again. I also we discussed with Ted and Troy, that they need to submit a plan to address how they are going to correct the quality of the water in the seep so that treatment is not necessary. The plan is to be submitted to the BOM for approval by May 1st, 2017.  Flowing pit water field tested a 7.5pH and 1 Fe. with no treatment.   Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. Pond #1 was discharging approximately 45 gpm at a 6.5 pH, <1 Fe... Pond #1 is at its 60% sediment storage capacity and the long reach hoe has been brought on site to clean the pond as soon as weather permits. Quarterly water quality and DMR reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  The washes/rills on Planting Report #1 were visually inspected and need repaired as soon as weather permits. Also the large bare area located down next to Ditch #1 and just above the top soil pile needs top dressed and reseeded & mulched.   If you have any questions contact this Inspector.

Mining is complete on this site.  As soon as the 575 dozer is repaired, Tri-Star Mining is to finish their portion of the backfill and reclamation.  The Permittee needs to make arrangements to finish the remaining backfill and reclamation that they are responsible for, in a timely manner.  Pond #3 was not discharging.

On this date BOM Director John Carey received a complaint from Mr. Randy Slayton. Mr. Slayton called to complain about dust, cracked foundation, crack in the living room ceiling, drain in driveway clogged with coal dust and that his yard was black.  I was off on this date so Mr. Carey handled the complaint and immediately went to the mine site and inspected the county and state road conditions for fugitive dust. His findings were that dust was coming from the anti-skid material. When the anti-skid material dries out it becomes airborne as vehicles travel through the area. Mr. Carey's written findings for this complaint are attached to and made part of this inspection report.  Mr. Slayton's blasting complaint has been investigated before with no violation found. Blast are monitored continuously with a stationary seismograph and are in compliance.  The site is being monitored 2-3 times per week for fugitive dust and blasting compliance is reviewed on a quarterly basis and/or as needed.
No discharge today. The reveg most recently planted looks good .  Any weak spots that develop will be treated this spring.
Repairs to reveg look good and will be reviewed when the grass begins to grow.  No germinination visible on the coal pad yet.

On site review today with John McDaniel, Ron Hameric, Rodney Tichinel, Nick Riggins, Rich Riggins, John Carey, Tom Murray, Ralph Mongold and Ron Schartiger  for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Today's meeting between Vindex Energy and The Bureau of Mines was called to address several issues and concerns on the SM-02-443 Island Mine Permit. The issues and concerns are as follows;  1. John Carey recommended installing perimeter berm and access road and then shutting down project until weather permits completion of the treatment system. 2. Tom Murray requested detailed schedule of the "Sequence of Activities" of the remaining steps for completion. 3. Ron Schartiger recommended a Pump Basin to be installed at the end system for maintenance purposes. 4. Vindex requested to divert any "Clear Water" off site instead of going through the system. 5. Vindex will be monitoring the seep at the base of the Slurry Pond. 6. Vindex will complete the excavation of the relocated treatment pond. 7. Vindex will monitor the new silt fence along the southern tip of the permit and make repairs as needed. 8. Vindex will clean mud and sediment from the S8 wetland. 9. Vindex will monitor the sump at S6 due to the roadway pushing into it. 10. Vindex will place stone or erosion fabric on the sides of the sump at S8 to protect the inlet and outlet pipes from plugging. 11. Vindex will perform daily inspection of the dividing berm at Wetland #7 due to the berm slumping and sliding. 12. Vindex will perform daily inspections of the entire treatment system. The Bureau recommended keeping a daily inspection log on site. 13. Vindex will schedule vegetative repairs for various locations on the permit. 14. Vindex will schedule rill and wash repair for various areas on the permit.  Please contact this inspector with questions or comments.

This was an onsite review of the sediment and erosion control plan with BOM  Inspection & Enforcment Supervisor Tom Murray, Contractor James Clark and the property owner Major Moran.  Due to site conditions, the sequence of construction is modified to the following:  1. Install the permit sign and perimeter markers.  2. The existing ancillary entrance to Pond #3 shall be stabilized according to Maryland E&S Manual, Detail B-1.  3. The rock located at the Pond #3 site will be removed and stockpiled out of the way. This rock will be broken using an excavator/hammer and will be used on site for rip-rap material .  4. The required silt fence for Pond #3 will be installed.  5. Cutoff Ditch A and B will be constructed, seeded and mulched as per the approved design.  6. Pond #3 will be constructed, seeded and mulched as per the approved design.  7. Ditch D and the access road will be constructed starting at Pond #3 and working uphill to the existing Permit SM-13-463 haulroad. The access road will be sloped towards Ditch D and all disturbances shall be seeded and mulched.  8. The main entrance for this permit and Permit SM-13-463 shall be relocated and constructed as per the approved Garrett County Roads Department.  9. Culvert's B&D will be installed under the main entrance haulroad along with sumps and then the remaining sections of Ditches B&D will be constructed, seeded and mulched.  When the sediment and erosion control facilities are finished, inspected and approved by the BOM, the excavation of the treatment ponds, mine face up area and transfer of material to fill/yard can begin as per the approved design plans.    Contact this Inspector if you have any questions.  Notify this Inspector when work begins.

Due to an excursion on Pond 002 in December the Operator has requested an onsite meeting. The Operator did notify this inspector by phone as soon as he was aware of the excursion.   The Operator did submit a letter as Per the NPDES on January 2, 2017 to this inspector.  A NOVO is being issued due to the non-compliant discharge reported on the DMR's as per the Operator. NOVO 461-170130-NOV is being issued and mailed to the Operator. Due to heavy rains and the clay like materials this was probably the reason for the excursion. The Operator has added additional sumps, with clean lime stone approximately 4 to 6 inch in diameter and has additional rip rap to the ditches since the last inspection.  With what was visible (due to frozen and snow on the sumps and pond) the sumps are clearing up.  This appears to be working.  In discussion with Wayne Boal the Operator's water sampler, he is to take an additional sample and submit to this inspector.  According to Wayne the Pond has been frozen over and not discharging.  As weather allows take an additional sample and submit to this inspector.  Due to the pond being frozen and no discharge, this inspector could not take a sample. Removing coal this date, discussed the permit with the foreman Eugene Liller. No discharge observed this date.  The additional sumps and rip rap ditch as per the NOVO has been completed. Therefore; NOVO 461-170130-NOV is being terminated this date.  Monitor Pond 002 and if the clay and soils continue to be a problem you need to consider discussing with a chemical company for treatment.  If there are any questions feel free to contact this inspector.

On site review today of the SM-11-459 Permit with Travis Rinker, Eddie Smith and Ralph Mongold for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  While traveling to the Island Mine, Permit SM-02-443, several issues were noted with the condition of the roadside sumps and berms of the SM-11-459 haul road. The issues were discussed with Vindex Energy personnel several weeks earlier on January 4th and again on January 13th, 2017.  It appeared that Vindex Energy made no effort to address the issues as discussed.  Today's inspection of the haul road, that connects permits SM-11-459 and SM-02-443, had several issues that required immediate attention. A combination of heavy traffic, lack of maintenance, snow melt and recent heavy rains have contributed to these issues.  A call was placed to the Mine Foreman, Travis Rinker. Within the hour, all issues were addressed, equipment was in route and stone was ordered to make all needed repairs.  I spoke with Mr. Rinker the following day, on 1-27-17; he informed me that all repairs were completed on 1-26-17.  The operator will need to monitor the haul road and make any needed repairs as required.   Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On site review today with Rodney Tichenell, Tim Clark, Nick Riggins and Tom Murray for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The site is active today. All Construction and Vindex Energy employees were working at the new treatment system. The treatment system is not discharging at this time; all water is being pumped to the slurry pond.  The Notice of Violation and Order that was issued on 1/10/17 stated that Vindex Energy is ordered to; Take ALL necessary precautions and actions to assure that any water leaving the permitted mine site meets Water Quality Standards and Effluent Limits.  Today's inspection is to address the precautions and actions that have been performed. To date, the following precautions and actions have been taken;  1. The Metal Recovery Units (MRU's) were taken out of service and removed from the water treatment system area. 2. A Flocculating agent drip has been added to the treatment system. 3. The 6" pipes from S8 have been extended into the sump at the Seep 8 area to keep mud and debris from obstructing the flow. 4. Additional mulching has been performed at various locations of the treatment system. 5. Stone has been applied to both the haul road and the interior access roads. 6. A larger pump basin has been installed in place of the MRU's and the smaller pump basin. 7. A primary and a secondary pump have been installed in the new pump basin. 8. Vindex Energy personnel are on the site 24/7 to monitor the treatment system and to address any issues that arise.  The Operator has taken adequate actions and precautions to terminate the Notice of Violation and Order. At this time, NOVO 443-170110-NOV is terminated.

On site review today of the SM-11-459 Permit with Rodney Tichnell, Eddie Smith and Tom Murray for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Reclamation of the entire permit is in progress. The operator was directed to concentrate all reclamation efforts to the Kittanning pit area. Please See Notice of Violation and Order 450- 161026-NOV, items # 2, #6 and #7 on Page #3. When weather does not permit reclamation on the Kittaning Pit areas and the construction of the swale to Pond #2, all work will be directed to the Freeport Pit reclamation.  Additional sampling points and sampling schedules were set forth in Notice of Violation and Order 459-161026-NOV, Please see Items #8, #9 and #10 on page #3 of the NOVO. In addition to the sampling points and schedules listed in the NOVO, two additional points and parameters were changed and or added during an office meeting with Vindex Energy on Tuesday January 10, 2017. The additional points and sampling schedules are as follows; Monitoring Well #3 (MW3) and the "French Drain" from the Kittaning Pit will be sampled bi-weekly. Aluminum will be added to the sampling parameters for the French Drain, MW3, SP1A, SP1B, SP2, SP3 and SP4.  The operator was directed to submit the water sampling data in a timely manner, (Please see item # 10 on page #3 of the Notice of Violation and Order 450-161026-NOV.) The required data is taking four to six weeks after the samples are taken to be submitted. The operator was directed to discuss these concerns with their analyzing laboratory and provide the sampling data on a timelier schedule.  Notice of Violation and Order 459-161026-NOV will be re-instated if the operator continues to disregard the directives provided on page #3 of the Order.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Office review today with Rodney Tichenell, Ron Hamerick, Nick Riggins, John Carey, Al Hooker, Tom Murray, Jeff Snyder, Mark Hajas and Ron Schartiger for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  An inspection on 12-29-16 resulted in water samples being taken below the MRU (Metal Recovery Unit) at the silt fence, adjacent to the perimeter marker. All Construction and Vindex Energy employees were working at the new treatment system. While performing a pump down procedure on a newly installed tank, the treatment system was overwhelmed, causing the MRU and a connecting pipe to be overtopped. This action allowed non-compliant water to leave the permit area at several locations. Water samples were collected and delivered to Geochemical Testing in Somerset PA for water analysis.  Today's office meeting is at the request of the Bureau of Mines. Vindex Energy was called in to discuss the SM-443 Coal Mine Permit, the cause of the incident, the results of the water samples and the schedule of completion for the water treatment system.  Several additional items were discussed during today's meeting; the MRU removal, the relocation of the existing treatment pond and the construction of a perimeter berm and roadway.  Results of the discussions are as follows;  The Bureau is requesting all construction at the new treatment system to be completed by April 10, 2017. (90 days)  The MRU's will be totally removed and abandoned by Wednesday January 11, 2017, as per Rodney Tichenell.  Work has begun on the relocation of the treatment pond, as per Rodney Tichenell.  When work on the relocated treatment pond is complete, Vindex Energy will begin construction on a perimeter road and berm to assure all water from the permit stays in the new treatment system.     A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued.  Please see the attached Laboratory Results and photographs of the MRU and connecting pipes overtopping.

Onsite review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The site is active today with All Construction employees and Vindex employees working at the new treatment system area. The new plastic pump basin that was recently installed is being replaced, due to structural failure, with a larger steel pump basin. When the plastic tank was pumped out to prepare for removal, a large amount of water was introduced to the wetland/treatment system in a short amount of time.  During that pumping procedure, the MRU tank and transfer pipe were overwhelmed allowing partially treated water to overflow the system and leave the permit at several locations.  Photos and water samples were taken. The water samples were delivered to Geochemical Testing for analysis.  Pending results of the water analysis, a Notice of Violation and Order may be issued.  Triad Engineering is on site today surveying elevations for the new Active Treatment Pond.   Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Onsite review today with Tom Murray for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The Treatment Pond at the new treatment system needs to be inspected and certified by an engineer. There are several reasons that the Pond Certification is required at this time. The pond was built on unstable fill material, it is showing signs of sliding on the out slope, there are cracks present in the breast, there is an old mine entry that is situated directly below the pond; the old entry recently collapsed into the toe of the embankment.  An alternate location of the treatment pond should be considered or immediate measures need to be taken to stabilize the embankment and ensure the structural integrity of the structure.  The Pond Certification will be completed and submitted to the Bureau by December 27, 2016. If the Pond cannot be certified, work on the relocation or stabilizing will begin immediately and will progress until complete.  Several additional issues at the treatment system required immediate action by the operator. The issues were corrected during today's inspection.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On 10/27/2016 a blasting complaint was received from Lisa Griffith at 12213 Carlos Rd., Frostburg, MD. Mrs. Griffith complained that a strong blast this morning rattled her house just after 9 am.  My investigation revealed that no blasting had occurred at the Carlos Mine that morning but the Cabin Run Mine did blast at around 09:05 am. A review of the Blasting Log and report revealed that a maximum PPV of 0.083 and Peak Air of 122 (db) had occurred and were well below the limits set forth by State and Federal regulations. So no violation occurred.  Mrs. Griffith was contacted and explained the findings.  No further action or investigation is required for this complaint.

On site review today with Ray Tighe, Mine Supervisor, Tom Murray, Supervisor of Inspections and Enforcement and Mike Garner, Abandoned Mine Lands Section Chief for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The operator called Tom Murray and myself and requested that we come to the site and inspect a slide that had occurred on the downhill slope of the permitted Haul Road. An approximate 50' wide area has slid down the hillside taking the MSHA roadside berm with it. At this time, the Haul Road does not appear to have stress cracks, slumps or sliding present, all movement appears to be from the road edge and below. Tri-Star Mining was in progress of replacing the MSHA Berm during this inspection.  Initial Inspections reveal Pre-Law deep mine workings on the Barton Coal Seam directly above the Haul Road and the active slide area. These old mine workings appear to be the major contributing factor to the slide and the heavy saturation of the hillside below the Haul Road.  With this Field Inspection report, the Bureau is granting Tri-Star Emergency Authorization to shift the permitted Haul Road into the road cut to assure the safety of all traffic that is traveling on the Haul Road. As-Built Drawings and new Haul Road mapping will be submitted to the Bureau with next year's Annual Progress Maps.  This Field Inspection Report also authorizes Tri-Star Mining to divert several Pre-Law Deep Mine drainages from the slide area. A drainage control ditch will be constructed above the relocated Haul Road to capture any mine drainage and reintroduce it in the existing roadside ditch away from the slide area.  Daily Shift Inspections will be performed on the Haul Road by Tri-Star Mining and any changes will be reported immediately to Bureau upon discovery.  Tri-Star Mining will take all precautions necessary and utilize the "Best Practices Possible" to control erosion and sediment from leaving the site during the Haul Road relocation and construction.  Mike Garner will contact OSM to discuss a potential AML Project at the slide area.   Fugitive Dust and a non-durable road surface has become an escalating issue on SM-436. The operator will need to take action to control the fugitive dust and provide a durable road surface. Paving or tar-n-chip surfacing is recommended.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Rills and gullies have been an ongoing issue on the Benard tract. The issues were discussed with the operator on multiple occasions. Tim Schwinabart agreed to placement of rip-rap stone in the larger rills and gullies and repairs on any other rills that are 9" or more throughout the permit area. The operator agreed to have the repairs completed by the end of August, 2016.  In August, the operator removed several cutoff ditches and reclaimed some the affected areas. Although an attempt was made, rill/gully repair was not completed as directed by the deadline given.  During September's inspection, multiple existing rills and gullies were located throughout the Benard tract. A call was placed to the operator and direction was given to repair all rills and gullies by a new deadline of the end of September 2016.  In an attempt to assist the operator, I tied surveyors ribbon at several locations to assist the operator in rill and gully identification and repair.  I have offered to meet with the operator on sight to identify the trouble areas on multiple occasions.  The operator has been instructed to call me when repairs were completed so a follow up inspection could be scheduled. As of today's inspection, the operator has not contacted me to schedule an inspection.    A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued on SM-02-441.         COMAR 26.20.14.05.B states;  In addition, except on lands eligible for remining, the period of liability for a bond shall continue for a minimum period of not less than 5 years, beginning with the last year of augmented seeding, fertilizing, irrigation, or other work. The period of liability shall begin again when augmented seeding, fertilizing, irrigation, or other work is ordered by the Bureau to correct a failure to maintain the permanent vegetative cover required under COMAR 26.20.29 on the site.  Planting Report #2 on SM-02-441's Bond Release 5 year period will restart when rill and gully repairs are completed and a Termination of Violation Inspection is completed.   Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On site review today with George Beener, the Operator, Ray Tighe, Mine Supervisor, John Carey, the Director of the Bureau of Mines, Tom Murray, Supervisor of Inspections and Enforcement and Ron Schartiger, ECS III, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  On July 5, 2016, a landslide was located below the SM-436 Permit. The slide appears to be related to Pre-Law Mining and Acid Mine Drainage. Today's meeting is to discuss ideas and options of diverting clear water from the un-mined areas of Tri-Star's Permit SM-436 and the previously mined G&S Permit SM-430 to natural drain ways on the North facing slope of Hampshire Hill.  Years of Pre-Law Mining have left spoil piles, old high walls and many areas of Acid Mine Drainage and seeps downhill from Coal Mine Permit SM-436. The affected areas are on the Franklin and Barton Coal Seams. The area consists of steep slopes, unstable spoil piles and heavily saturated areas from Acid Mine Drainage Seeps from the Pre-Law Mining activities. The Abandoned Mine Lands Section of the Bureau of Mines has completed several AML Projects in the immediate area attempting to control several landslides along the hillside and have utilized the installation of Iron Slag Leech Beds sediment ponds to clean up some of the Acid Mine Drainage.  After discussing several ideas and options, the Operator and the Bureau of Mines decided that a Clear Water Diversion Ditch along the Little Pittsburgh Coal Seam Crop Line will be installed in conjunction with a series of Clear Water Traps at the Eastern permit boundary to regulate the flows of clear water during heavy rain falls and snow melt from the un-mined areas of the Tri-Star SM-436 Permit and the previously mined G&S SM-430 Permit. The discharge of the clear water will be a controlled discharge and directed to a natural drain way instead of introducing additional water to the areas that are affected by the Pre-Law Mining and Spoiling.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Inspection today, with Michelle Arrington and Bill Murphy present, in response to a complaint by Jeremy Jacobs.  Mr Jacobs stated that runoff from permit 440 had entered his house. A rainfall event occurred last evening at around 8pm in excess of two inches. This quantity of water appears well beyond the capacity of the county road ditch. We observed that velocities were sufficient to blow the stone rip-rap liner out of several long  sections of the road ditch near the residence. It appears that excessive stone is present for the volume of ditch available. This may have contributed to flooding in the lower level of the basement. There was also damage from flooding to an upper level room. This was from water in the back yard originating from an invert in the woods upgrade from the house. It is estimated that approx. 10 acres of revegetated mine land out of a  total of  20 acres of land are in the contributing drainage area. Runoff from the active portion of permit 440 drains down an valley south of the Jacobs residence. I telephoned Allegany county  roads engineer Adam Paterson and advised him of the situation.

This site is approved for "Temporary Cessation of Mining Activities" from 5/15/2015 to 8/15/2016.  On this date I met with Al Hooker, Mark Hajas and Ted Schwinabart to investigate the seep that has developed in the backfill. Three samples were taken for analysis; S-1 at the start of the seep, S-2 where it is concentrated into a natural ditch that flows down beside the topsoil pile to Ditch #1, and S-3 which is on the east side of the pond road and flows into the east pit and then to Pond #1.  Until sample results are received and studied to make a conclusion, construct a ditch which will catch all of S-1 and direct it to a constructed sump and let it discharge into the existing natural ditch. Set up treatment at the discharge of the sump and monitor weekly taking samples (before treatment) and keep normal field sampling records. The samples need to include pH, flow, iron, manganese, suspended solids, acidity, alkalinity, aluminum, specific conductance, dissolved solids and sulfate. Submit the lab analysis sheet by e-mail to Al Hooker and me. If you have any questions contact this Inspector or Mr. Hooker.  There are rills, washes, bare areas and a highwall slump that need repaired soon to avoid a violation. These areas have been marked with flags in the field.  Pond #1 was discharging a 6.0 pH, 1130 Specific Conductance, 1.2 Fe @ 63 degrees F...

Review of permit with Jody Ritchie and Rusty Bush.  A sweeper truck was in operation cleaning the county road on this date.  Operator is loading a shot on the Redstone this morning.  A blasting complaint was received from Mr. Randy Slayton. Mr. Slayton said that this blast was the worst he had ever felt. He also stated that it knocked things off his walls and almost knocked him off his feet.  I immediately called the Foreman Rusty Bush and had him e-mail us the shot report and the seismograph report. BOM Director John Carey and I reviewed the reports and found the shot to be in compliance with State and Federal Laws. The seismograph showed a ppv max. of 0.160 and the max. air pressure was 127 db.  I contacted Mr. Slayton and explained our findings. He was not happy with the findings and asks if we could seismograph at his residence. I told him that the BOM and the blasting company, Wampum, would monitor the next blast at his residence. I have also required that Beechwood Coal have their contract blaster, Wampum, seismograph all shots at the Slayton residence until further notice.  No violation was found and no further action will be taken concerning this complaint, however the BOM will continue to monitor blasting activities at this site.

The operator has reviewed Comar 26.20.22 with Tom Murray, Inspection and Enforcement supervisor, and submitted the required lab data from outfall #001 .  Therefore NOVO  454- 160324-NOV Violation 1 of 2 and 2 of 2 are terminated. Conclusion from the Enforcement Conference: The Operator is actively pumping and treating water from Bakerstown pit.  The Operator will clean bottom of pit and place lime and clay cover with approximately 12 inches or so of material. By April 12, 2016 the Operator will submit plans to this office for the Bakerstown mining or reclamation. Violation 2 of 2; Backfilling on the Harlem Coal Seam. Conclusion from the Enforcement Conference: This Violation stands, by April 18, 2016 the Operator will begin spreading remaining topsoil, and planting the area unfinished portion north of open pit. While conducting this Enforcement Conference it was decided by all parties to discuss questions that exist regarding the NOVO 454-160324-NOV, Violation 1 of 2; required seismograph record at nearest dwelling not provided. Conclusion from the Enforcement Conference: Violation stands, Seismograph records for nearest dwelling not recorded. Violation 2 of 2; manganese discharge in excess of effluent limits. Conclusion from the Enforcement Conference:The Operator will clean bottom of pit and place lime and clay cover with approximately 12 inches or so of material. While pumping the Operator is treating pit water with additional chemicals, lime, soda biscuits, and potassium permanganate.  NOTE: The Operator may request a hearing by the Department to review the notice or order according to COMAR       26.20.31.10 .10 Formal Review. A. Within 30 days of issuance of any notice of violation or cessation order, or within 10 days from receipt of the Bureau's decision after an enforcement conference, whichever is later, an operator may request a hearing by the Department to review the notice or order. Formal review may also be requested by any person having an interest which is or may be adversely affected by a notice of violation or cessation order, or by any modification, vacation, or termination of any notice or order, provided that the request shall be submitted within 30 days of the action. All requests shall be submitted to the Bureau, in writing and signed by the requestor, and shall contain: (1) The full name and address of the person requesting the hearing and a telephone number where he can be reached during normal business hours; (2) The name, address, and telephone number of any attorney representing the requestor, or a statement that he intends to represent himself; (3) A detailed description of the grounds for the request, including the interests of the requestor which are or may be adversely affected by the decision of the Bureau; (4) A statement of the specific relief desired; (5) A general outline of the evidence to be presented in support of the desired relief at the hearing, including the names and addresses of all witnesses expected to be called by the requestor. B. Formal review hearings shall be conducted in accordance with COMAR 26.20.34. The Bureau shall have the burden of proof as to the validity of the notice or order, or modification, termination, or vacation of it. C. The filing of a hearing request does not operate as a stay of any notice or order, or other action for which review is requested. The requestor for a hearing may file with the hearing officer a written request that the hearing officer grant temporary relief from any notice or order, together with a detailed statement of the reasons for granting the relief. The hearing officer shall issue a decision granting or denying the temporary relief as expeditiously as possible. The hearing officer may grant temporary relief, under those conditions considered appropriate, pending final determination of the proceeding, if: (1) All parties to the proceeding have been notified and given an opportunity to be heard on a request for temporary relief; (2) The person requesting temporary relief shows that there is a substantial likelihood that he will prevail on the merits of the final determination of the proceeding; (3) The relief will not adversely affect the public health or safety, or cause significant imminent environmental harm to land, air, or water resources; and (4) The relief sought is not the issuance of a permit where a permit has been denied, in whole or in part, by the Bureau. D. Inability to comply with a notice or order is not grounds for vacation or termination.

On this date a review of the procedures used for taking flow measurements at re-mining sampling point's SP-10, SP-16, SP-17, SP-18 and the UNT of Moore's Run were conducted as part of an OSM Oversight Follow-Up Inspection. Present were Tom Cunningham & Joe Montrella with OSM; Nick Riggins & Grant Reed with Vindex Energy; and Al Hooker, Mark Hajas & I with the BOM.  Sampling procedures for collection and flow measurements were observed and noted to be in compliance with the standards required by Federal & State Laws.  Also a review of the BOM's ongoing hydrological investigation to determine whether the iron stained drainage that is  entering the UNT of Moore's Run is caused by the adjacent old mine workings & spoil or is a result of mine drainage from this permit. This concern was observed during the December 15, 2015 OSM oversight inspection.

On site review today with ray Tighe, Mine Supervisor, and Ralph Mongold, Lead Inspector, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Today's inspection is at the request of Mr. Steven Stafford, a resident of Westernport MD. Mr. Stafford requested that the Bureau of mines set up a seismograph at his residence at 101 Kelly Ave, Westernport, MD. Ralph Mongold and I set up the Bureau's seismograph for the shot that was scheduled for today. At 10:03, the seismograph triggered an event and the readings were as follows; PPV-0.0456 and dBL-91.5. Both were well below the maximum allowable limits. Mr. Stafford was with us during the shot and agreed that no other testing would be required at the time.  No issues noted  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On site review today with Mark Arnold, Site Contractor for the operator, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  An attempt has been made to place rip-rap in the drainage control ditch. Portions of the ditch remain washed out and additional rip-rap is required. Also, the operator has affected the vegetative cover on the out slope of the drainage control ditch where he ran equipment across it to make the needed repairs. No attempts were made to repair the vegetation. Seeding and mulching is required.  Several rills remain on the backfilled areas, no attempts have been made to repair the rills and washes.  The operator was instructed to clean up and remove any coal and or coal cleanings from the old screening and stockpile areas. It appears that the operator attempted to just cover the Acid- Forming and Toxic-Forming Materials instead of removing the material and placing it in the backfill. Mark Arnold was directed to remove the topsoil that was spread by the operator, place the potentially toxic material in the backfill as per the Approved Coal Mine Permit and then spread top soil, seed and mulch as required.  There are several Notice of Violation and Order's and Failure to Abate Cessation Order's outstanding on this permit.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

Office review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Today, the results from water samples that were taken on 2/01/16 at Outfall 001 on Permit SM- 12-460 were reviewed. Both Total Suspended Solids and Turbidity were elevated above effluent discharge limits.  The laboratory reports show Total Suspended Solids @ 143 mg/L. The NPDES Permit requires that the Daily Maximum for Total Suspended Solids is not to be over 70 mg/L.  The laboratory reports show Turbidity @ 207 NTU. The NPDES Permit requires that the Daily Maximum for Turbidity is not to be over 100 NTU.  A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued.  Any questions or concerns, please contact this inspector @ (301)697-0344.

On site review today with Aaron Miller and Tom Murray for the purpose of Inspections and Enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The operator notified the Bureau of Mines of a slurry line leak at 8:00 AM. The leak was on an adjacent property to Mettiki Coals Permit, the Neal Stone Property. The operator identified the leak, shut down the slurry pump, constructed several hay bale dykes to contain the slurry and had begun cleanup efforts by the time Tom Murray and I had got there. Mettiki Coal was instructed to continue with clean up, add additional hay bale dykes and add a large hay bale sump to catch any additional slurry from the leak area. Mettiki had already taken stream samples of Sand Run and have scheduled water sampling to continue twice daily as needed. Sample results will be submitted to the Bureau of mines as they come in. Daily Monitoring will continue until further notice.  Mettiki Coal and property owner Neal Stone agreed to allow Mettiki Coal to install an access road to the lower pasture field to the North of Dobbins Road to access the slurry spill area and assist in cleanup efforts. This inspector Field Approved the access road construction.  The leak in the slurry line was repaired on Friday January 8, 2016.  Any questions or comments, please call this inspector @ (301)697-0344

On this date I conducted a blasting complaint investigation that was reported to the BOM by Franzy Zembower. Her residence is located at 13001 Burning Mines Rd., Frostburg, MD  21532.  Mrs. Zembower called and complained that the blast conducted today around 11:45 am was very hard and shook the whole house. This was the worst she had ever felt.  I contacted Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel and got a copy the blasting report and the seismograph reading. The seismograph had a maximum ppv of 0.288 and 116 db air reading, all well below the allowable limits set forth in State and Federal laws.  I called Ms Zembower back and explained that my investigation found that the company was in compliance with State and Federal laws. I also explained that she will feel the blast but the vibration received would be well below the threshold of any damage.  No further action concerning this complaint is needed at this time.

This was an OSM oversight inspection conducted with OSM Inspector Joe Montrella and Vindex Energy Environmental Compliance Specialist Nick Riggins and Grant Reed.   The operator was backfilling with 2 dozers on this date.   The re-vegetated areas look good.   Drainage and sediment control facilities were functioning properly. Pond's #3, #5 and Trap's 4A, 4B and 4C were not discharging. Water quality and discharge monitoring reports are being submitted with no violations noted.   We reviewed the site locations of sampling points S-5,SP-16,and SP-17. The sample point S-5 was not flowing. Joe took grab samples of SP-16 and SP-17 for lab analysis comparison.  Joe questioned Nick about their method of measuring flows. Nick responded stating that a weir is used to measure the flows and that the weir is put in place each time flows are measured. Also the weir is not left in place until the next sampling period because it would get covered up with debris because of the wooded area and it will get coated with iron residue. Also there is concern that the bears will displace and break the weirs up.   While there, Joe walked up the UNT to the headwaters of Moore's Run and collected a sample. Joe made note of his concern about the UNT headwaters of Moore's Run and questioned if it was required to be monitored as a sample point. I explained that as per the approved NPDES permit this location is not required to be sampled.   Joe plans to do continue his investigation of the permit with a background check of the water quality data and comparison of his samples.

On this date I conducted a dust complaint investigation that was reported to the BOM by Mr. Randy Slayton. His residence is located at 12905 Vale Summit Rd., Frostburg, MD  21532.  Mr. Slayton called and complained about a 6' crack in his ceiling and that there is black dust on his house, vehicles and lawn furniture. Also he claims that his voice has been messed up for the past six months and the dust is having an effect on his health.  BOM Inspector Ron Schartiger and I met with Mr. & Mrs. Slayton at their residence on this date.  At first we discussed the crack issue. I explained to them that there were three separate seismographs recording all blast that are conducted at the Cabin Run mine site. The peak particle velocity (ppv) readings are well below the maximum limit allowed by State and Federal Law. Secondly we looked at outside of the house, vehicles, porch rugs, lawn furniture and shrubbery. There was a considerable amount of visible dirt/dust on everything outside which he believes is coming from the Cabin Run surface mine site. I explained that there is at least two other sources of possible contributories of fugitive dust because of the location of their residence, which is located at the intersection of Maryland Route 36 and Vale Summit Road. This intersection is a heavy traffic area and the active county landfill site is located within 1/2 mile of their residence. At the conclusion of our conversation I stated that I would meet with Vindex personal to investigate and discuss their problem. Mr. Slayton requested that I have someone from the mining company contact him so that he could voice his opinion with them.  Ron and I then went to the mine site to do an inspection and investigation due to the complaint. There were no visible signs of fugitive dust leaving the site during the inspection. We then met with the day shift foreman to discuss the complaint and advised him that the complainant has requested to meet with their company officials concerning his complaint.  On 12/14/2015 I met with Vindex Energy Officials Thomas Jones, Rodney Tichinel and Nick Riggins at the mine site to discuss the complaint and any additional measures that could be implemented to control fugitive dust that is generated by the heavy truck traffic going to and from the Cabin Run surface mine site, noting that there are other sources not associated with the mining site that are contributing to the problem. Some of the possible solutions that were discussed were, sweeping the intersection of Cabin Run Road and Route 36 and washing the pavement of Cabin Run Road while the roads are closed during blasting. We also discussed the installation of a wheel-wash at the mine site. At the conclusion of our meeting I requested that Mr. Jones prepare a chronology of the cooperative steps that have been taken to reduce fugitive dust generated by the mining operation and any additional plans that may be put in place for the further reduction of possible fugitive dust. He is to submit the chronology to this Inspector. Also Mr. Jones stated that they were meeting with Mr. Slayton to address his complaint.  Monitoring this site for fugitive dust is standard procedure for monthly inspections.  No further action concerning this complaint is needed at this time.

On site review for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Mine is active. Coal is stockpiled and is being trucked off of site. The treatment systems looks good with no issues noted.  A spring has surfaced along the Haul Road just north of the access road to the new water treatment system. The spring has saturated the Haul Road and has washed coal fines and sediment down the road surface which in turn is being deposited onto Durst Road from the coal truck traffic. The entire length of Durst Road from the mine entrance to Rt 495 is covered in dirt, dust and gravel. I had placed a call to the Mine Office to have the sweeper truck begin cleaning the road surface.  As the water ran down the Haul road surface, it could not flow to the drainage controls. The drainage ditch for that area of the roadway flows to Pond #003. It had sediment build up in the inlet which allowed the surface water to run down to the road culvert, through a sediment trap (that was full) and spill into the county maintained roadside ditch along Durst Road that flows to the North Branch of the Casselman River. The water was laden with coal fines and sediment. Samples were taken.  The Mine sent two men and a Skid-Steer Loader out to redirect the flow of the spring water. An attempt was made to re-open the drainage control ditch inlet, but the inlet was too narrow for the Skid-Steer to open the ditch as needed.     I placed a call to DJ Elliott, Engineer for Maryland Energy Resources, and instructed him to have the road graded, sloped and capped with clean stone by Monday, December 7, 2015. The Mine Clerk, Jerry Donaldson, informed me that Maryland Energy Resources, as per Joe Gallo, would not be doing the required road grading, sloping and capping over the weekend as I instructed. I was informed that the work would be scheduled for the following week.  A Notice of Violation and Order will be issued.   Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

On Site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Pond #5 has several feet of water but it is not discharging. On this date I conducted a dust complaint investigation that was reported to the Baltimore Office, LMA/ Mining Program Manager Mr. Ed Larrimore, by Mr. Roy Arnold.  His residence is located at 13710 New Georges Creek Rd., Frostburg, MD  21532.  Mr. Arnold called Mr. Larrimore and complained that dust is blowing off the Cabin Run Mine and onto his property. He also stated the he believes that they are hauling in illegal reject material (from the Mt. Storm wash plant) and stockpiling it on site and when it dries out it blows onto his property.  I first went to the mine site and spoke to Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel. We traveled the mine site and looked at the reject pile in question. I ask for their cooperation in grading the reject pile to reduce the elevation of the pile so that it will not be visible to Mr. Arnold. He agreed and said that it would be taken care of first thing tomorrow.  I contacted Mr. Arnold and discussed his complaint. I told him that no reject material was be hauled in from the Mt. Storm wash plant. He did not believe me though. We discussed the reject pile located on the Cabin Run site and how it is being used. He doesn't believe they are hauling much of it because he can't tell that the pile is being reduced. I then told Mr. Arnold that I spoke to Rodney and that the pile would be graded down tomorrow and would not be visible to him anymore. He said that would be ok and that was what he wanted.  No further action is needed concerning this complaint.

On this date I conducted a blasting complaint investigation that was reported to the BOM by Mr.Peter Darr on 11/12/2015. His residence is located at 16111 Harwood Drive, Frostburg, MD 21532.   Mr. Darr complained that on 11/12/2015 at approximately 12:05 PM he felt a strong blast. He also stated that cracks have been forming on the basement foundation walls and the concrete floor over the past 6 months and are getting more severe. He also stated that other neighbors in the area are experiencing similar foundation problems from blasting that is conducted at the Cabin Run Surface Mine.   The Darr residence is located approximately 1.9 miles from the permit boundary (see the attached Google Map). The closest seismograph used to monitor this shot and to evaluate this complaint was located near the Pasty Smith residence and is 2,821 feet from the actual blast site. The review of the blasting report and seismograph analysis report show that the maximum PPV recorded was 0.045 and the recorded peak air pressure was 114.6 db. These readings are well below the allowable limits set forth by State and Federal laws.   I called Mr. Darr and explained that the operator is in compliance with the blasting limits set forth by State and Federal law. He was not satisfied with my findings and said that he was going to contact the Media and get something done. I advised Mr. Darr that if he was not satisfied with my findings he could contact the Director of the BOM John Carey and speak to him directly. I then gave him the director's phone number.  This complaint and my investigation findings were reviewed by the BOM Director John Carey and it was determined that no further investigation is warranted.
No discharge today, ponds are dry.  The reveg looks good.   No problems observed.

On Site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Pond #5 has several feet of water but it is not discharging. pH is 7.2; Specific Conductance is 140 and 53 degrees.  The Field Inspection Report 450-151014-FIR specified several areas that the vegetation has died off. The steep slope area just above the Old Pond #1 location, as well as any other sparsely vegetated areas throughout the permit, will need to have the required amounts of lime, fertilizer, seed and mulch applied by December 31, 2015.  Several large washes have formed above and below the Old Pond #1 location. Several attempts have been made by the operator to repair the rills without success. The operator will submit a schedule for the removal of Pond #5 along with any associated drainage control ditches. If Pond is to remain, the operator will submit documentation from the landowners of the request for Pond #5 to stay in place. The Schedule for reclamation or the Request for Pond #5 to remain will be submitted to the Bureau by December 31. 2015.  Any questions regarding this inspection, please call this inspector at (301) 697-0344

Inspection of the surface area of the deep mine site was conducted today with ARJ Engineer Kevin Clark.  They are actively deep mining on one section, one production shift. Coal is being processed and loaded onto trucks for shipment.  An examination of Pond #1 showed that the pond was not discharging however the water in the structure field tested a 3.8 ph and 10+ iron. I instructed Mr. Clark to immediately treat and circulate the water in the pond so that any discharge would meet effluent limitations.  On this date a group from OSM and MDE were on site for a tour of the mining facility.  This complete inspection was continued on 11/10/2015 with a review of the Net DMR's that were submitted for the 3rd Quarter of 2015. The review for the month of July 2015 showed that there was a  noncompliant discharge of the effluent limitations of pH and manganese at Pond #1, Outfall 001, which resulted in  the following violations;  COMAR Title 26.20.21.02(B.)  Water Quality Standards and Effluent Limitations. Discharges of water from areas disturbed by surface mining shall be made in compliance with applicable State laws and regulations, the federal Clean Water Act, and with effluent  limitation for coal mining promulgated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency set  forth in 40 CFR 434.    Also you were in violation of Section II (B. 2.) of the GENERAL CONDITIONS of your NPDES Discharge Permit  which states; If, for any reason, the permittee does not comply with or will be unable to comply with and daily maximum or daily minimum effluent limitation specified in this permit, the permittee shall notify the Inspection and Compliance Program by telephone within 24 hours of becoming aware of the noncompliance. Within five calendar days, the permittee shall provide the Department with the following information in writing:  a.  a description of the noncompliance discharge including its impact upon the receiving waters;  b.  cause of noncompliance;  c.  anticipated time the condition of noncompliance is expected to continue or if such condition has been corrected, the duration of the period of noncompliance;  d.  steps taken by the permittee to prevent recurrence of the condition of noncomplying discharge;  e.  steps to be taken by the permittee to prevent recurrence of the condition of noncompliance; and  f.  a description of the accelerated or additional monitoring by the permittee to determine the nature and impact of the noncomplying discharge.   You are hereby ordered to submit in writing, by November 30, 2015,  how you will avoid any possible noncompliant water quality standard and effluent limitations of discharges to the waters of the State and how you will insure compliance with the general conditions of your NPDES Permit. Send to the BOM, 160 S. Water St., Frostburg, MD 21532 , and Attn: Ralph Mongold.
