On 10/26/2015 a blasting damage complaint was reported to the BOM in person by Mr. Eric Keating. His residence is located at 12750 Vale Summit Rd., Frostburg, MD.  The reviews of the blasting records indicate that the PPV's are well below the allowable limits set forth by State and Federal laws.  On this date Jeff Snyder and I visited the residence and investigated the alleged blasting damage complaint. This residence had a pre-blast survey completed on 2/24/2015 that showed cracks in the basement block wall mortar joints. The cracks that the home owner is concerned about are also in the block wall mortar joints. Mr. Keating stated that he thinks the cracks have gotten worse since the pre-blast survey was done.  We explained that the operator is in compliance with the blasting limits set forth by law and the history of how the limits were established. We also explained that the cracks in the block wall mortar joints, that were documented in the pre-blast survey and presumed to be getting worse, are due to normal settling of the foundation. Mr. Keating was advised that if he was not satisfied with my findings he could contact the Director of the BOM John Carey for another opinion.  No further investigation is needed concerning this complaint at this time.

On site review with Mine Superintendant, Randy Fogle for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The purpose of today's inspection is to address a Blasting Complaint that was filed by Mr. Gary Granger, 146 Maple Grove RD Grantsville, MD. Mr. Granger stated that on 10-21-15, around 1:30 AM he was awakened to his house shaking. He also stated that several flat screen TV's were dislodged from their stands and dishes in the cupboard was moved.  After talking with the Mine Superintendant, Randy Fogle, this inspector was informed that no blasting has been performed on the mine site, either underground or on the surface. There are no blasting materials stored on site and the mine does not have the proper permits filed with MSHA or the Bureau of Mines to allow blasting.  After two attempts to reach Mr. Granger by the phone number given, a message was left on his answering service that stated that the mine is not blasting nor have they blasted since the issuing of the mining permit. I recommended that Mr., Granger notified the Maryland State Fire Marshall of his concerns.  The Bureau of Mines will take no further actions on this complaint at this time.  Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

On this date Vindex Energy hosted a group from the Chinese Delegation / State Administration of Coal Mine Safety for a tour of the mine site.  On 10/16 2015 a complaint was received from Mr. Lew Engle, 12803 Vale Summit Rd. SW, Frostburg, MD.  Mr. Engle phoned in a complaint stating that dirt and flyash is blowing off the mine site and onto his vehicles, barn and house. I called Mr. Engle and discussed his complaint. He said that the dust & dirt was mainly gray in color and felt that it was flyash and he was concerned about his and his girlfriends' health. I explained to him that Vindex was taking all reasonable actions, such as watering the interior rock truck haulage roads and additionally the use of water cannons to control fugitive dust during the truck loading of overburden in the Sewickly pit area and the truck loading of coal refuse at the stockpile area. I also explained that the flyash comes in from the AES Warrior Run plant with a certain percentage of moisture to help keep it from becoming airborne and as per their approved permit the ash is to be covered daily with backfill material. Air Quality has also made site visits to the mine because of complaints of fugitive dust and found the site to be in compliance with State Laws.  I will continue to monitor the site.  No further action is needed for this particular complaint.

This is an OSM Oversight Inspection conducted with OSM Inspector's Joseph Montrella and Christian Canary.  Coal mining operations were being conducted on several different seams. The annual monitoring report for stream restoration of Staub Run, which is part of the off-site mitigation work that is required in their NTW Permit, was reviewed and observed in the field.  Other than cleaning Ditch #2, there were no other environmental problems or concerns.

Office review today for the purposes of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines  Today's Inspection Report is to address a Blasting Complaint that was filed by Mr. Roger Fazenbaker on 9/29/2015. I took the complaint by phone. Mr. Fazenbaker stated that the recent shot shook his home in Westernport. The Tri-Star Mine SM-00-436 is located above the town of Westernport on Hampshire Hill. After receiving the Blast Complaint, I called Ray Tighe, Tri-Star's Mine Superintendant, and requested that the Seismograph Reports to be sent to the Bureau of Mines for review.  A review of the Seismograph Report showed the PPV was 0.0439 and the dB (L) was 112.0. COMAR limits all blasts to a maximum PPV of 1.0 and a dB (L) limit of 133. Tri-Star Mining is well below the allowable limits. The blast on 9/29/2015 is in compliance, No actions will be taken by the Bureau of Mines in regards to the complaint or the blast.  Any questions, please call this inspector, Ron Schartiger, at (301) 697-0344

On site review today with Bob Huston and Dave Bowers, Water Managers for MER, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Liners have been installed in Treatment Cells A and B. A vacuum truck is on site today cleaning Treatment Cell C; the liner for Cell C is scheduled to be installed on Monday September 28th.  Pond 001-B has an area of seepage that has gotten progressively worse over the past several months. The area is at the base of the breast just above the Outfall 001-B Building. The seepage has progressed from a seep to a flow with piping present along with heavy saturation of the base of the breast. The Bureau of Mines has directed the operator to install a liner in Pond #001-B.  Dave Bowers asked if the Bureau of Mines would consider water samples to assist in identifying that the water that is coming out of the Pond #1-B embankment in not mine water but is from another source. This inspector agreed to review the sampling results and any other documentation the MER would like to provide, but until the sample results are provided and ample time is given for review, MER will continue on the schedule that was set forth  in Field Report DM-113-150916-FIR to have the liner installed in Pond #001-B  As per the approved Coal Mining Permit, if the mine is idle for more than 30 days, the operator will make preparations and begin work on the Mine De-Watering Well.  Pond #001 is discharging @ 180 GPM, pH-7.5.      The operator had discussed with the Bureau adding a new meter to the discharge line coming from the mine, this is to allow for accurate monitoring of all water that is being pumped from the mine to the surface. The operator will install the new meter as discussed, before mine start up.  Maryland Energy resources will contact this inspector before any coal production begins.  Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

On this date a complaint was received Mr. Ronald Arnold, 13710 New Georges Creek Rd., Frostburg, MD.   Mr. Arnold called BOM Director John Carey and complained that dust from a visible coal stock pile (refuse stock pile) was causing a problem at his residence. He stated that they have to clean the patio and pool every time they want to use them.   Mr. Carey contacted me to discuss the complaint. We reviewed the other recent complaints made by Mr. Arnold and discussed my findings that concluded that the site is in compliance with our laws. Because of the complaints I have required additional fugitive dust control measures which include watering the area and use of a water cannon during truck loading activities at the refuse stockpile area and that no additional coal or refuse may be stockpiled in that particular area.   I also advised Director Carey that Mr. Arnold has made complaints to ARMA Inspector Tamara Davis about fugitive dust problems. She has made several inspections at the site and investigated dust complaints filed by Mr. Arnold. We called Miss Davis and spoke to her about the complaints on this site that she has investigated. She replied that the site has been investigated for fugitive dust complaint's and found to be in compliance during her inspections.    On this date I observed the site from a high vantage point. Interior haulage roads were being watered. The active overburden removal area was creating some fugitive dust in the pit area but it did not appear to be leaving the permit area.   I will continue to monitor the site for fugitive dust problems.  No further action is needed for this particular complaint.

On site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  On September 16, 2015, during an inspection, Dave Bowers notified me that on 9/14/15 the mine had exceeded the 290,000 Gallon Per Day Limit. The exceedence was 900 gallons over the allowable limit.  On September 17, 2015, MER Engineering Manager, Rob Bottegal, notified the Bureau of Mines in writing as required by their Individual Discharge Permit, Section II. B.2 of the exceedence. Mr. Bottegal also provided the Bureau of Mines with the documentation from the Open Channel Flow Weir System that is used to monitor the flow at the discharge point. As stated in the Accuracy Section of the information provided by the manufacturer, the accuracy of the weir in most field conditions is 5% to 15%.  The exceedence that was reported by MER was approximately 0.34% over the allowable discharge limit. The 0.34% is well within the limits of accuracy as stated in the information that provided by MER and the manufacturer.  MER will not receive a violation for the discharge exceedence.  Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

Review of the permit area today with Vindex Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel.  The operator was mining on multiple coal seams removing overburden and loading coal out of the pit. Pond #2 was not discharging. This structure collects a lot of coal fines from the coal processing area and needs to be cleaned out to avoid possible water quality issues. Pond #3 was not discharging. Pond #4 was not discharging. Trap #5 has been cleaned and was not discharging. Water quality and discharge monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  CCB's are being dumped on site, mixed into the backfill and covered daily as per the approved permit.  Blasting records are kept on site at the mine office. There have been no blasting violations noted during this quarters review.

Inspection of this site today with Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rusty Bush.  The bare areas on Planting Report #7 have been re-seeded and top dressed.  The coal processing equipment is being dismantled and they are cleaning up the base layer of the upper coal storage area.  Trap #7 was discharging a 6.9 pH, 6500 specific conductance @ 65? F...

Backfilling with three dozers on this date.  A minor surface water drainage problem near Trap #4C was discovered and was immediately corrected by the Superintendent, Rusty Bush. Pond#3 was not discharging. This structure is now eligible to be reclaimed. Pond #5 was not discharging. General Permit MDG852427; Trap's 4A, 4B and 4C were not discharging. Water quality and discharge monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  The main haul road was being re-graded and maintained in good condition on this date.  The sump at the culverts on h aul road #2, off of Potomac Hollow Road, needs cleaned.  Continue backfilling until reclamation is completed.

On site review today with John Carey, Director of the Bureau of Mines and Jeff Snyder, Permitting Section of the Bureau of Mines, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  As of August 19, 2015, the three new treatment cells have been operational. The cells were required to assist in the treatment of mine water before it discharges at Outfall 001.Today's inspection is to address several concerns that are associated with the three new treatment cells as well as several concerns with existing Pond 001, Cell B.  Treatment Cell A has an area of seepage at the base of the breast embankment. It is unable to retain water.  Treatment Cell B has an area of high saturation, an area of slide, an area of slumping and a crack that runs almost the entire length of the breast. It is unable to retain water.  Treatment Cell C has a small area of saturation at the breast an area in the cut slope of the cell that appears to be a sink hole and a crack that is perpendicular to the breast.  Pond 001-B has an area of seepage that has gotten progressively worse over the past several months. The area is at the base of the breast just above the Outfall 001 Building. The seepage has progressed from a seep to a flow with piping present along with heavy saturation of the base of the breast.  After visual observation by the Bureau of Mines, the Bureau has determined that Pond Liners will be required at all three treatment cells and in Pond 001-B.    As of Friday September 11, 2015, the mine is idle, so therefore, you are directed make any needed repairs to the treatment cells and to have the new liners installed in Treatment Cells A and B before the mine starts back into production. Treatment Cell C will have a liner installed within two weeks after mine start up.  A liner will be installed in Pond 001-B within four weeks of mine start up.  As per the approved Coal Mining Permit, if the mine is idle for more than 30 days, the operator will make preparations and begin work on the Mine De-Watering Well.  The operator had discussed with the Bureau adding a new meter to the discharge line coming from the mine, this is to allow for accurate monitoring of all water that is being pumped from the mine to the surface. The operator will install the new meter as discussed, before mine start up.  Maryland Energy resources will contact this inspector before any production begins.  Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

On site review today for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  The site is not active today. All of the coal from the last pit has been removed. Mining has progressed through the old deep mine entry. Lime is deposited at the old deep mine entry to treat water, pH at the old mine entry before treatment is 3.5 and the Specific Conductance is 240  Currently, there are two open pits in increment #1, one at the Old Mine Entry and one just to the West of the Old Mine Entry. The operator has been instructed to remove any coal cleanings and or any toxic materials from the pits and place lime on the pit floors. Both pits will be cleaned of any coal cleanings, lime placed on the pit floors and a minimum of four feet of clean non-toxic overburden placed in the pits by October 31, 2015.  The Flocculating Agent tanks, used to treat for turbidity, appear to be empty. Additional Flocculating Agents will be brought to the site by October 31, 2015.  A portion of the area above the drainage control ditch has been seeded and mulched. Additional seeding and mulching is required above Trap #1 and along the perimeter control ditch. The additional seeding and mulching will be completed by October 31, 2015.  A large area of Increment #1 has been rough backfilled. The operator will provide the Bureau a schedule of when the area of Increment #1 will be backfilled, seeded and mulched.  Trap #1 is discharging, pH-8.6, Specific Conductance-220 and 69 degrees.

On site review today with Joe Gallo, Vice President of MER, for the purpose of inspections and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Mining is in progress. Coal is stockpiled and is being trucked off site.  A large area of the breast of Treatment Cell B has slumped. An approximate 100' long crack has formed and has slid down the embankment due to apparent heavy saturation of the pond embankment at the base. The eastern end of the slide has dropped approximately 18" and the western end of the crack travels well into the width of the breast. Immediately upon discovery of the slump/slide, the management of MER was notified and was directed to drain Treatment Cell B via the draw down pipe. All mine water was to be directed to Pond 001-A for treatment before discharge. MER was instructed to have their engineers inspect all three of the treatment cells and schedule any required repairs.  Joe Gallo, Vice President of MER, informed me that the mine was going to idle production for several weeks. Maintenance crews would still be on sight.  The sump at the coal yard is at the 60% clean out level. The operator was instructed to have the sump cleaned in the coming weeks,  Any questions or comments, please contact this inspector, Ron Schartiger, @ (301) 687-0344

No one working on site today.   Repair large gully on the Barton reveg.  Treat  Bakerstown pit water,pump it out and treat the pavement. Then begin backfilling pit to eliminate pit water. Met on site with Ted today.  Ditch #1 has been cleaned as directed.  Pond #1 was not discharging. Water in the structure tested an 8.2 pH. The ground water coming out of the backfill is being treated.  Ted has requested to reverse approximately 500' of fresh water Ditch A because he believes that the undisturbed surface and ground water that is entering the fresh water ditch is infiltrating into the backfill and causing a problem. After reviewing this in the field I feel that he may be correct and I am approving the fresh water drainage ditch modification. This modification is for the 0-500' of Ditch A which will be reversed to run west to an undisturbed section of the permit area. This reversed section of ditch must end on the undisturbed permitted section on the west side of the permit in a stable area and/or be protected by a rock outlet.  Continue backfilling and adding large amounts of alkaline material.  There can be no additional mining/coal removal until the site is backfilled and planted up to the pond access road which will make the site compliant with contemporaneous reclamation.

This was an OSM oversight inspection conducted with OSM Inspector's Joe Montrella, Christian Canary and Contract Operator Tri-Star Mining General Mine Foreman Raymond Tighe.   They were actively removing overburden from the Franklin coal seam today.   Tri-Star did attempt to clean inline Pond #1 as directed. More time was granted to complete the work due to wet conditions.  Pond #3 was not discharging.  The trees have not been cut/removed as directed. Within two weeks, cut/remove the trees off the constructed pond embankment to avoid a violation.  Ditch #1 has been cleaned as directed. The review of the approved blasting plan revealed that the contract operator is using 7 7/8" drill bit which is not approved. The current plan calls for using a 6 1/4"-6 3/4" drill bit. G&S Coal was contacted about the problem and did submit a request to modify their Blasting Plan to include up to an 8" drill bit. This request was approved by the BOM on 8/24/15.

On August 11, 2015 this inspector collected a discharge sample from Pond 001 due to the color of the discharge.  After receiving the lab results, the Operator is in violation of the Total Suspended Solids.  According to the lab results your TSS was recorded as 55. The required tonnage reports for compliance to NOVO Number SM463-150811-NOV have been received by the BOM therefore the violation is TERMINATED.

A review of the site with Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel was conducted today due to a dust complaint received from Ronald Arnold, 13710 New Geroges Creek Rd,, Frostburg, MD. Mr. Arnold complained that there is black dust covering his house and pool. Also trucks are causing additional dust on the road.  I contacted Mr. Arnold and we discussed his concerns. He stated that he could see a pile of coal from his residence and that dust was coming from it. He also said that Vindex was not watering the interior roads and the rock trucks were making a lot of dust. I told Mr. Arnold that I was on site this date and that there were three water trucks in service and watering today. As far as the coal pile that he can see, it is reject material which is to be loaded for shipment to AES.  The following week Mr. Arnold called and complained that when Vindex was loading the reject material onto trucks there was an extreme amount of dust being made. I addressed this with Rodney and directed them to use their water cannon when loading the reject material and to water the stockpile down as necessary until the reject stockpile is gone. He agreed and will do what is necessary to control any fugitive dust. No further action is needed for this complaint.  CCB ash is being handled as per the approved permit.

As per DM111-150615-NOV the MW-1 pool monitoring data was submitted on the updated form provided by the BOM.  On this date, BOM Permitting Chief Al Hooker and I met on site with ARJ Engineer Kevin Clark to observe the required sampling of MW-1 mine pool for water quality. The submersible pump had been installed and was working.  The MW-1 mine pool water level was at 350'.  I took field test samples during the operation which are as follows: Pumping began; water tested a 6.9 pH, 2400 specific conductance and 10+ Fe. Water was pumped @ 12 gpm for 10 minutes in order to clear the system and then samples were taken for lab analysis. Field test at this time were; 6.75 pH, 2600 specific conductance and 10+ Fe.  The above actions satisfy the order and requirements of the NOVO therefore DM111-150615- NOV is terminated.

A review of your water quality and discharge monitoring reports showed non compliance with the following: As required per the letter from Mr. Alan Hooker, Chief of the Coal Permit Section, Maryland Bureau of Mines dated April 8, 2015; you were to immediately submit mine pool monitoring data, obtained to date, from the monitoring well MW-1 which includes mine pool elevations and water quality data.  Quality samples were to be obtained during both April and later during the second quarter of 2015.  Pool monitoring and water quality data was to be reported to the Bureau electronically as soon as practical after results were obtained, and on the paper Monitoring Report form provided by the Bureau and submitted quarterly with the other Water Monitoring Reports for this permit.     The above modifications to your approved ground water monitoring plan were not complied with thus resulting violation #DM111-150615-NOV is being issued.   As a result of the violation you must immediately submit the MW-1 pool monitoring data on the updated form provided by the Bureau. By June 30, 2015 collect the MW-1 mine pool quality sample and submit it to the lab for analysis. Submit the MW-1 mine pool water quality lab results to the Bureau on the updated form as soon as you receive them.   The main entrance haulroad was in satisfactory condition.

On 6/10/2015 a complaint was received from Ronald Arnold, 13710 New Georges Creek Rd. Frostburg, MD. Mr. Arnold is claiming damage to bricks and blocks from blasting activities conducted at this mine site. On 6/11/2015 I met with Mr. Arnold and discussed his concerns and took pictures of the bricks, blocks and the concrete walk at the pool. (See the attached pictures.) Mr. Arnold has a mason on site making repairs to the bricks and basement wall.   I compared my pictures to the pictures in the Blast Survey that was conducted on his residence in 2002. I explained to Mr. Arnold that Vindex Energy is and has been in compliance with their blasting activities and that the blasting limits, which are in place by law, would not cause the damage that he is suggesting. Mr. Arnold understood what I was explaining to him but did not agree. Before leaving Mr. Arnold requested to have the mining company contact him concerning this issue. I talked to Rodney about the complaint and told him about my findings and that Mr. Arnold wanted to speak to someone from the mining company. Rodney will pass the request on to company officials.    On this date a second complaint was received from Mr. Bob Robertson, 13402 New Georges Creek Rd. Frostburg, MD. Mr. Robertson complained that it was very dusty on Rt. 36 near the Landfill and stated that he almost wrecked his truck because of the dust. In my investigation it is noted that a shot had been put off just before this incident and caused a cloud of dust, which is normal during blasting activities. I called Mr. Robertson and explained my findings and that Vindex Energy has a fugitive dust control plan which they are to follow during mining and blasting activities. In their plan one of the conditions is that they monitor weather conditions, including wind direction so that the shot can be fired at a favorable time that will minimize any affects of fugitive dust. He said he understood that, but this issue was much worse than normal. I advised Mr. Robertson that I will notify the company of his complaint and I will remind them of the conditions in their fugitive dust control plan.

Discussed with Bob Huston and Melissa Santiago and they would send this office an explanation of the flow if there were any problems.  Don has stated he would send Melissa a report of the flows.              Also while on site the office received a complaint from Thomas Klosterman, coal dirt and dust build up on Durst Road.  Which the office phoned me at 2:16 P.M... This inspector was on site from 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M...  The complaint was received by the office at 2:00 P.M...  While on site the water truck continued to water the haulroad and Durst Road.  When I entered the site via Durst Road and exited the site via Durst Road, the road was saturated with water.  While on site I can't remember the amount of times the water truck filled up (loaded with water) at Pond 001.  Since the operator is trying to keep flows below there required limits for Outfall 001, the water truck runs continuous.  I can not explain where the dirt and dust was coming from because I did not visibly see that at the time I was at the mine site.

Onsite inspection of permit conditions today with BOM Inspector Ron Schartiger and Savage Mt. Foreman Roy Hartman.  The end wall has sloughed off into the open pit. Roy was working on stabilizing the area by making a bench across the end wall. This area is adjacent to the area that was previously surface mined by Tri-Star Mining.  After reviewing the surface area above the end wall it was discovered that three surface cracks have developed making it an unstable and unsafe condition. Mr. Hartman was ordered not to work on this area without another person on site to watch for movement of the unstable material. Also the area is to be worked from the top down by sloping the material back to a minimum of a 1:1 down to the bench level and then so forth and so on as required by the MSHA acknowledged Ground Control Plan. Mr. Hartman agreed to follow my order. Also special order to cut off all surface water going to this area was approved by this Inspector and will remain in effect until the area is stabilized and made safe to continue mining.  Sediment and drainage control facilities are functioning properly. Pond #4 was not discharging. .

This site has been approved for temporary cessation of mining activities for a period of 6 months from January 1, 2015 to June 30, 2015.  Mark Carney and I reviewed Planting Report #6 for 43 acres. The required trees have been planted on this area and will be reviewed by the LRC on 5/6/2015.

On this date a blasting complaint was received by phone at the BOM office.  Helen Warnick, 13605 New Georges Creek Rd. SW, Frostburg MD, call and complained that the blast today at 10:05 a.m. seemed very hard and caused items in her curio cabinet to rattle. She also stated that recent blast have been very hard.  I called Rodney and got a copy of the blast log and seismograph reports. The maximum ppv was recorded at the Landfill Office with a 0.0225 reading and 107.5 peak air pressure. This is well below the limits set forth by State and Federal laws.  I contacted Miss Warnick on 4/16/2014 and explained my investigation findings. She understood and I then advised her not hesitate to call if she had any other concerns.  No further investigation is needed for this complaint.

Reviewed the permit area this date and discussed with Ted Schwinabart... Auger mining on Increment II just west of the haulroad area.  No auger activity this date, according to Ted the auger machine has moved out for a few weeks and then they are moving back to complete the augering on Increment I. Discussed with Ted to repair rills on planted areas on Increment I and Increment 2 Complete construction of Ditch 4 to Pond 004 area, seeding and mulching will be better as weather conditions allow.  This ditch, Ditch 4, need the stumps that were pushed on the outslope removed and graded to a 2:1 and tracked in for stability.   As discussed previously as weather conditions allow Pond 004 construction will be completed.

On site review of the permit area with Ray Tighe the Foreman for the Operator. On 4/8/2015 Edgar McKenzie phoned in a complaint concerning dust at his residence located at 13516 New Georges Creek Rd. SW, Frostburg, MD.   I contacted Mr. McKenzie and met him on site this date. I inspected the dust on the garage doors and the window seals on the house. This dust material appeared dark grayish. I explained to Mr. McKenzie that it would be very difficult for me to conclude that all the dust had come from the Cabin Run Mine and not from the winter abrasive material that is used on Route 36. I also explained the fugitive dust control plan that is in place at the mine site and that it is being complied with.   Mr. McKenzie also stated that last year a representative from Vindex Energy had called and talked to him and they were supposed to get back with him and meet him at his residence.   No further investigation is needed at this time however I will be monitoring the site for fugitive dust control.   Also on this date BOM Director John Carey, Tom Murray, Ron Schartiger and I met on site with Vindex Energy staff to discuss a temporary location to screen rations. This was approved for a six week period beginning this date and to end on 5/27/2014 as long as no fugitive coal dust problems occur.  Your are reminded to use good judgment not to operate this equipment during dry and/or windy day.  While on site we also reviewed the backfill and the area being prepared for revegetation. It was discussed that some of the area being used to park equipment should also be backfilled and reclaimed to stay in compliance with contemporaneous reclamation.

This site has been approved for temporary cessation of mining activities for a period of 6 months from January 1, 2015 to June 30, 2015.  I met with Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rusty Bush and Grant Reed to discuss the 4 wheeler and dirt bike traffic, vandalism and trash & debris dumping that is occurring at this site. This has become an environmental and public safety issue. Trails that have been created by the 4 wheelers and dirt bikes have destroyed some of the vegetation on reclaimed areas and pond embankments.  These areas will need to be repaired. Recently a pickup load of household debris has been dumped near Pond #4. As we reviewed the debris a bag of household garbage was discovered and a prescription bottle was found inside. The prescription bottle had a name and address on it. Rusty said they would contact the authorities with the information to see if anything could be done about it and the trespassing issue.  4 wheelers and dirt bikes have been riding dangerously close to the highwall edge. Rusty, Grant and I walked the entire highwall and discussed cutting down tree across the trails to stop them from riding along the highwall. Rusty is to see that this gets done.  This site has two entrance points with locked gates. It was discovered that the pickup truck gained entrance by going around the secondary entrance gate (green gate).  Rusty is to see that this area is blocked.  As far as 4 wheeler and dirt bikes, there are numerous access points and it will be difficult if not impossible to stop them without 24 hr. security.  They are also riding dangerously close to the edge of the highwall. These areas will need repaired. I will be meeting on site with Vindex Mine Superintendent Rusty Bush to review the damage and discuss how to try to prevent them from riding along the highwall.   Water quality and discharge monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.
This is an AML reclamation project managed by the  Bureau of Mines.  No discharge today. Standing water has a pH of 7.2.

Conducted a field review with Bob Huston the Environmental Coordinator for the Operator and his Supervisor for Water Manager of Corsa, Dave Bowers.  Reviewed drainage facilities and ponds and discussed.  On site meeting scheduled this date to review slide above Pond 002 area.  Present for the meeting was Rich Wagoner, Manager of Engineering and Matt of the Engineering Department. Also on site was John Carey the Director of the Bureau of Mines and Jeff Snyder of the Permitting Section for the Bureau of Mines.  The meeting this date is to review the slide above Pond 002 and discuss ideas of repairing.  The Operator is to going to submit a work schedule a tentative plan for the Permitting Section to review.  While reviewing the slide area it was discovered that a slide had developed below Ditch 2 about a northwest direction from Pond 002.  We reviewed this area and this area is a priority and will be addressed immediately.  Rich will contact this inspector and advise what progress has been done this date to address the slide.  By phone later this date Rich called this inspector and advised that Joe Gallo has instructed them to notify S & S Construction to look at and mobilize equipment to start construction on the slide.  The goal is to have the equipment on site by the end of this week and start moving material off the slide area by Monday.  This is going to be a work in progress and the Inspection and Enforcement will meet on site with representatives of the Operator as needed.  Any questions contact this inspector, John Carey or Jeff Snyder.             Discussed in detail with Rich the haulroad maintenance, keeping clean shale on road way, brooming road way, and cleaning road ditches. Also discussed with Bob after meeting with Rich that maintenance on haulroad ditches and possibly sloping haulroad toward ditch line area due to the truck traffic squeezing the ditches closed.  The haulroad being sloped and the berm on the upper portion of the road will allow well beyond the freeboard required in the approved permit.  Recommend a grader on site for road maintenance.  Also monitor and repair berm on haulroad as needed, the berm has appeared to have settled through the years of operations.

On sight inspection today with Rich Riggins, Nick Riggins and Grant Reed for the purpose of inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Pond #1 has water but no discharge. Pond #6 is discharging with a pH of 8.0, Specific Conductance of 2,800 and a temperature of 45 degrees. The tree planters are on site today and have approximately 56 acres scheduled for planting. Nick Riggins, Grant Reed and Ron Schartiger walked the southern perimeter of the permit from Pond #3, around the southern point to Pond #6. There are three areas at the southern portion of the permit, Seeps 6, 7 and 8 that are discharging heavy flows of non-compliant water. Seep 6 has formed at the edge of the permit boundary, Seep 7 is inside the permit limits close to the old Pond #7 location and S8 is along the Right Prong just east of the old Pond #7 location. Seep 8 is off of the permit boundary approximately 70 yards. Photographs were taken of all three areas.  April 8, 2015, office review. A meeting was held at the Bureau of Mines. John Carey, Tom Murray, Al Hooker, Jeff Snyder, Mark Hajas and Ron Schartiger were in attendance. Vindex Energy provided water sampling data for both the streams and the seep areas. After reviewing the water data, the photographs and discussion on site conditions, it was determined that the three discharges of are the direct result of mining operations that were performed on SM-02-443 by Vindex Energy. A meeting was scheduled with Vindex Energy for 4/13/15 at the Bureau of Mines

Over site inspection with OSM Inspector's Joe Montrella and Christian Canary on this date.  Coal is being stockpiled on the site.  Pond #1 was frozen and not discharging. Recently during a rain event the pond had discharged with obvious coal fines noted at the discharge outlet. This was due to the water level being frozen below the discharge inlet and allowed the coal fines from the stockpiled to be suspended and carried across the frozen pond and out the discharge pipe. However the pond does appear to be almost at its designed sediment storage capacity and needs cleaned.  The following maintenance must be completed within two weeks to avoid a violation; 1. The pond must be cleaned and the coal fines below the discharge outlet must be cleaned up. 2. The internal sump on the south side of the permit area needs enlarged and cleaned.  These requirements were discussed with Ted Schwinabart.

On site review of the permit area this date with Jim Clark the Operator. The Operator is hauling coal from the permit area this date. Reviewed the location of Pond 001 area and discussed digging on the lower portion of the Increment I area to locate the crop line of the coal with an excavator. The Method of Operation is being revised and approved this date by this inspector and reviewed by Jeff Snyder of the Permitting Section for the Bureau of Mines.  The original Method of Operation is for Cut 1 to begin at the Pond 001 area and mine in a northern direction.  Due to the winter months the Operator is taking a cut at the far north of the Increment 1 area and utilizing the pit as in pit water storage.  If any water builds up in the pit it will be pumped to Pond 002. This office does not recommend constructing a pond during the frigid temperatures.  Once Pond 001 is constructed the mining will commence from the Pond 001 area and the far north area in sequence, therefore, allowing the Operator to have 2 open pits.  If there are any questions feel free to contact this inspector or Jeff Snyder at the Bureau of Mines.

Conducted and OSM oversight this date with Joe Montrella, Christian Carnay, Tom Cunningham and Brad Shultz of OSM and Jim Ashby the Permits Manager and Aaron Miller the Environmental Coordinator for the Operator. The inspection began at the AMD Plant with an explanation of the Plant and Treatment Facilities at the Plant.  Conducted water sampling at Deep Well # 3 with a ph of 6.6, collected a sample at the Pond 002 outlet with a pH of 7.4, and a sample at the Clarifier with a pH of 8.3. According to the flow meter for Pond 002 at the time of the inspection the Operator was discharging 7.4 mgd at this outfall. We then proceeded to the coal stockpile area, and Pond 006.  Reviewed and discussed. Then proceeded to Pond 010 and the sumps along the haulroad adjacent to belt # 34, and then Pond 005 and reviewed and discussed.  From here we proceeded to Pond 009 and sampled and conducted a field pH of 8.89.  Pond 009 discharges into a Trib to the South Fork of Sand Run which the water flowing in this trib was real muddy, Joe collected a sample and we investigated up stream to the problem area.  Adjacent to the road was sumps and the one was collecting water from the road way.  The grader was grading the road way and the thawing ( the temperature at Aaron Office was 42 degree Fahrenheit) was causing run off.  At the sump at the area to access Pond 005 was discharging muddy water into the Trib.  Within minutes of finding the situation Aaron contacted the contractor and a backhoe was at the site to clean the sump.  At this time I advised Aaron there would be a NOVO issued.  Within an hour or so we revisited the area and the sump was partially clean and the sump was not discharging and the Trib was clearing up and the muddy water was about gone.  This inspector with issue NOVO DM101- 150204-NOV. From this area we proceeded to Ditch 1 and Pond 001, Refuse 2 area and also Pond 008.  We reviewed and discussed these areas and at the time of the inspection the Operator was cleaning Pond 008.  The OSM Personnel's conducted measurements and measured slopes of the Refuse 2 area adjacent to Pond 008. Proceeded to Pond 004/013 area which is Refuse 3 area.  Perimeter controls and Pond are intact but there has been no refuse placed on this area as of this date.   Proceeded to Pond 012 area which consists of D Mine area.   Pond 012 was sampled and it field tested 8.35 pH.  Reviewed and discussed this area.  This has concluded the field inspection, which Joe and I discussed and a NOVO will be issued as previously noted.  According to Joe the inspection is completed in the field but he has some questions about the bonding which he will discuss with Al Hooker the Chief of Permitting or John Carey the Director for the Bureau of Mines.

The Bureau of Mines received a complaint on December 2, 2014 form Mr. Mark Beachy. The complaint was in regards to a blast that was set off at SM-00-436 at 10:55 AM. After speaking with Ray Tighe, Site Supervisor for SM-00-436, and a copy of the Blast Logs were faxed to the Frostburg Field Office. A review of the blast logs revealed that the PPV was at 0.11 and the decibel level was 113.8 dB. The readings of the seismograph report indicated that Tri-Star Mining was well below the 1.0 PPV allowance and well below the 133 dB limit. No violation will be issued.  Since 6/09/14, Mr. Beachy has called in three complaints for blasting on SM-00-436. All three blasts were well within the allowable state and federal limits. An audit of the blast logs performed by this inspector revealed that all blasts performed on SM-00-436 in the past year have been in compliance.

During last months' flight inspection, washes and rill on the hill to the right of Pond #5 were noted and water in the pit area looks bad.  Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rusty Bush and I reviewed the above concerns.  A small dozer will be brought in to spread fly ash and cover the pit water and will be used to fix the rills.

During last months' flight inspection, washes and rills to the west of the office building, fugitive dust while loading off-road trucks and red water below the coal stockpile area concerns were noted.  I spoke to the Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel about the above mentioned rills, fugitive dust and red water.  Rodney scheduled the repair of the rills with Contractor Jimmy Carter while I was on site.  We discussed more usage of the water cannon when spoil is being loaded off the Sewickly coal seams.  The red water is due to internal sumps that were made to treat ferruginous surface runoff from coal stockpiles'. This water is being treated at these sump locations well before entering the discharge drainage control structure.  Sediment and drainage control facilities were functioning properly. Pond #1 was not discharging. Water in the structure field tested an 8.5 pH. Pond #2 was dry. Pond #3 was not discharging. Water in this structure field tested an 8.3 pH. Pond #4 was not discharging. Water in this structure field tested an 8.3 pH. Trap #5 was frozen and not discharging. Water quality and discharge monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.    Blasting records are on file at the mine office with no violations noted.  Coal is being processed and loaded onto trucks for shipment.  The Redstone coal stockpile is smoldering and needs to be extinguished. This was discussed with Rodney.

On site review today with Johnny Carey and Mark Carney for the purposes of Bond Release Inspections for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Today's inspection is to review Phase I, (32 acres) Phase II, (planting report 4, 9 acres) and Phase III (planting report 1, 4 acres) Bond Releases. The vegetative cover on all of the areas in question appears to meet the standards for Bond Release. The landowner requested that the Haul Road, Pond #2 and Pond #4 were to remain.  Approval for these three structures to remain was granted by the Bureau of Mines, OPA 14-41. Ponds #1 and #3 have been reclaimed. There were no representatives from the landowner present and no objections were made.  Any questions or concerns regarding this inspection, please call this inspector at (301) 697-0344.

Contract Operator Tri-Star Mining was mining and removing overburden from the Franklin coal seams today.  During last month's flight inspection, washes and rills on the revegetated area and backfilled area were noted. Also Pond #3 appeared to need cleaning.  The rills are on an area that may be re-disturbed if additional area to mine the Franklin coal seams is requested. This should be decided by this coming spring. If the area is not going to be re-disturbed, then the rills will need to be repaired at that time.  Pond #3 is at approximately at 40-50% sediment storage volume and will not need cleaned at this time. Pond #3 was not discharging on this date.

A complaint was recently phoned in to the office stating that the 10-16-14 shot at this site was excessive. This was a follow up inspection to the blasting complaint that was received on 9/16/14 from Janet Slayton. On 9/18/14, I conducted a blast complaint investigation in response to a call received from Janet Slayton, 12905 Vale Summit Road, Frostburg, MD on 9/16/14; concerning a "sever blast" from the Vindex Cabin Run Mine at approximately 1:45 pm on 9/16 that the home owner alleged caused a crack the ceiling in her house.  On this date Jeff Snyder and I set up the seismograph at the Slayton residence, 12905 Vale Summit Rd., Frostburg, MD, to monitor the production shot that was being conducted at the Cabin Run Mine. Seismic readings from this shot registered a max. ppv of 0.075 and a peak air pressure of 113. These readings are well within the allowable limits set forth in State and Federal regulations.  Also we reviewed the pre-blast survey that was conducted on 1/29/13.  Mrs. Slayton was contacted and explained the results of our investigation.  No further investigation is required at this time.

On 9/16/2014 a blasting complaint was received by phone from Janet Slayton at 12905 Vale Summit Rd., Frostburg, MD. She stated that a severe blast occurred on 9/16/2014 around 13:45 - 13:50 and caused the drywall to crack. She also discussed a dust problem that is coming from the job.  I contacted Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel and advised him of the complaint and requested a copy of the seismograph reports for this particular blast. Mr. Tichinel e-mailed the requested seismograph reports. The seismograph reports showed a max. ppv of 0.14 and a peak air pressure of 119.9 dB. These readings a well below the allowable limits set forth in State and Federal regulations. I contacted Mrs. Slayton and reviewed my findings with her. She stated that she would like for us to take some seismograph readings at her residence. I told her we would.  On 9/18/14, Jeff Snyder met with Mr. Randy Slayton at their residence to discuss the complaint and to install the Bureau's seismograph near the house to record today's blast.  Mr. Slayton indicated to Jeff that the blast on 9/16 had extended an existing crack that been created from previous blasting located in the living room ceiling.  Jeff was then shown a repaired crack in the back of the house exposed block basement wall.  Mr. Slayton next indicated that when it rains hard they get water into the basement from the wall in the front of the house (front wall is total below surface grade and is finished on the inside).  The blast went of at 12:31 pm; the Bureau seismograph recorded ground vibration of 0.065 in/s PPV and air over pressure of 109.5 dB.  Because the blast today was only 12 holes and not a normal production shot, Jeff informed Mr. Slayton that we would come back out to monitor when the next production shot is scheduled. This investigation will be continuing with a review of the Pre-Blast Survey that was conducted at this residence on 1/29/2013 and Jeff and I will monitor the next production shot, at their residence. On site review of the permit area this dates with Aaron Miller the Environmental Coordinator for the Operator. Reviewed the Coal Yard Stockpile area and all drainage facilities, sumps and ponds appear in good shape. The drainage facilities at A portal area and Breaker Plant areas appears to be in good condition. D portal area appears drainage facilities are in good operational condition. B and C portal areas have been reclaimed and are well vegetated. Working Refuse 2 area this date. Watering roadways while conducting inspection. Ponds field tested this date as noted: Pond 002 - 8.1 pH, 1510 Conductance and 58.7 degree Fahrenheit with 10.61 mgd, Pond 007 - 9.99 pH with 1870 Conductivity and 64.5 degree Fahrenheit, and Pond 012 - 8.0 pH with 1320 Conductivity and 62.8 degree Fahrenheit. At this time I am conducting a NPDES Inspection of the Facility. The Coal Mine Operation is located on 813 acres of land along Table Rock Road in Garrett County, Maryland.  During the inspection I met with Aaron Miller, Environmental Coordinator for the Mettiki Operation.  We began our inspection with a meeting in Mr. Miller's Office to discuss the Permitted Area and a general review of the issued NPDES Permit. PERMIT VERIFICATION Mettiki Coal, LLC Discharge Permit renewal became effective as of October 1, 2010.  It will not expire until September 30, 2015.  Reminder the NPDES Permit expires September 30, 2015, submittal of the renewal needs to be submitted to the Baltimore Office by September 30, 2014.        RECORDS AND REPORTS Mettiki Coal, LLC is required to submit a monthly Discharge Monitoring Report.  (General Condition II-A.2).  In addition they are required to maintain a logbook of inspections and maintenance of their treatment system. The following is a list of documents on hand as requested by this inspector: Instrument Calibration Logbook Discharge permit Discharge Monitoring Reports Emergency Response Plan Instrument Calibration Logbook Operations Logbook Operator's Certification Material Safety Data Sheet Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (Updated October 2010), recommend to update with the renewal of the NPDES Permit Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan (Updated September 2010), recommend to update with the renewal of the NPDES Permit. OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE Wastewater discharge by the Mettiki Operation consists of mine drainage, Preparation Plant Wastewater, and Storm Water run off. Mine Drainage water and some of the storm water is treated at an Acid Mine Drainage (AMD) facility.  Runoff not treated at the AMD plant is treated in sediment basins.  The water there is treated with soda ash and caustic when needed.  Preparation Plant wastewater is periodically discharged to a series of ponds, which in turn discharge to the AMD Plant.  The AMD Plant was built in 1998.  The system consists of a Neutralization/Aeration Tank and one large Clarifier.  The Clarifier overflows into one of the old settling basins and then to a Polishing Pond.  The new treatment lines use the high density sludge process which circulates lime from the Clarifier back to the Neutralization/Aeration Tank.  Polymer is injected between the two.  The Polishing Pond outlet is defined as Outfall 002. Sludge generated at the AMD plant is discharged to a sludge tank and mixed with de- sulfurized solids from a nearby power plant and Preparation Plant sludge.  It is then pumped through a pipe underground to abandoned "C" Mine. A SUMMARY OF THE VISIT TO EACH PERMITTED OUTFALL FOLLOWS:  Outfall 001- This outfall is a sediment basin located below the active refuse disposal area.  There was no discharge at this location.  Wastewater from this location flows to a borehole where it is transferred underground to the AMD Plant for treatment.  This basin requires routine maintenance and has recently been cleaned.  Outfall 002 - This outfall is located below the Polishing Pond at the AMD Plant.  Flow and pH were measured and recorded at this location as 8.1 pH, 1510 Conductance and 58.7 degree Fahrenheit with 10.61 mgd.   An inspection of the Office and Treatment Plant found them clean and organized.  Outfall 005- This outfall is a sediment basin spillway located below a stabilized coal refuse pile. There was no discharge at this location.  Wastewater from this location is pumped to the AMD Plant for treatment.  Outfall 006 - This outfall is the last in a series of three cells (basins) located below the Coal Preparation Plant.  There was no discharge at this location.  Wastewater from this location is pumped to the AMD Plant for treatment.  The cells are routinely dredged of fines that are transported to a refuge pile for disposal.  The sumps along the roadway appear to receive routine maintenance and they have recently been cleaned.  Outfall 007 - This sediment basin receives runoff from the "A" Mine yard.  The discharge of this outfall field tested 9.90 pH with 1870 Conductivity and 64.5 degree Fahrenheit.  This outfall is allowed up to 10 pH for treatment of manganese.  Outfall 008 - This outfall is a sediment basin receiving runoff from "B" Mine yard and the active refuse area.  This mine is now closed. There was no discharge at this location during the day of this inspection.  Wastewater from this location is injected to a borehole between the basin and Outfall 001 and flows underground to the AMD plant where it is pumped for treatment.  This location is just below a reclamation area.  Outfall 009 - This outfall receives water from the sediment basin below the Breaker Plant.  No discharge was observed at his location. Outfall 010 - This outfall is a sediment basin located opposite the preparation plant.  There was no discharge at this location.  Wastewater from this location is first pumped to 006 where it is then pumped to the AMD Plant for treatment.  Outfall 012 - This outfall receives storm water run off and oil/water separator effluent only.  There are three cells at this location, "A","B", and "C".  The discharge of this outfall field tested 8.0 pH with 1320 Conductivity and 62.8 degree Fahrenheit.  SELF MONITORING PROGRAM  Flow Measurement  With the exception of Outfall 002, flow at the remaining outfalls is measured by determining the time required to fill a 5 gallon bucket.  The results are converted and reported as gallons/minute. A Siemens Totalizer, Chisel Strip Chart Recorder and ultrasonic flowmeter automatically measures and records flow at Outfall 002 only.  Sampling  An Isco Automatic Sampler collects 8-hour flow proportioned composite samples at Outfall 002 only.  An Ertco, #1387, mercury thermometer recorded a refrigerated temperature of 4oC during the day of this inspection. Laboratory  Wastewater analysis for  Mettiki Coal, LLC is contracted to two independent laboratories. Wastewater samples are normally analyzed by Standard Laboratories of Belington, W VA, and Sturm Environmental Laboratories of Bridgeport, West Virginia, are used on certain occasions.  During my inspection, I reviewed the Laboratory Analysis Sheets and found them to be complete with analyst, outfall, water quality parameter, standard method of testing, sample preservation, results, dates and times of the testing.  Chain of custody was maintained.  Storm Water Pollution Plan  The Mettiki Coal, LLC Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan was available for my inspection.  INSPECTIONS AND FINDINGS OF THE NPDES DICHARGE INSPECTION:  (1) I observed the general condition of the facility's outfalls to be in good order.  All outfalls were adequately maintained.  Ponds and basins appeared sound and secure. (2) There were no unusual odors at any of the outfalls inspected. (3) There was no evidence of bypassing at any of the treatment processes (4) The current NPDES Permit for the Mettiki Coal, LLC was on hand for inspection. (5) Operator Joe Snyder maintains a logbook.  It was available for my inspection. (6) The Mettiki Coal, LLC is submitting their Discharge Monitoring Reports in a timely fashion. (7) Joe Snyder Certification Number is 7542 for Industrial 2 and 5, Water Treatment 3, and Wastewater.  His certification was on hand for my inspection.  It does not expire until 2/1/2017, 7/1/2017 and 11/1/2015 respectively.  Jim Ashby, Manager of Environmental Affairs, Environmental Manager his Certification Number is 3291 for Industrial 2 and 5, Water Treatment 4, and Wastewater.  His certification, for all expires until 8/01/2017.  His certification, was on hand for my inspection.   Aaron Miller is a Temporary Operator Certification Number 5184 for Temporary Industrial 2 and expires May 1, 2016.   His certification, was on hand for my inspection.  Gary Lucas Certification Number 6436 for Industrial 2.  His has expired on 12/1 2013 and needs renewed.   His certification was on hand for my inspection. (8) Mr. Miller informed me that all storage tanks are located above ground and are either double walled or contain secondary containment. (9) An inspection of an above ground storage tank as noted: AST 1-D-1 - 1000 gallon with 80W90 oil, AST 5-D-1 - 1000 gallon with used oil, AST 5-D-2 - 8000 gallon with hydraulic oil,  AST 6-D-1 - 10,000 gallons with diesel fuel, AST 6-D-2  - 1000 gallons with motor oil , AST 7-OFF-1 - 6000 with gasoline,  AST 8-PREP-1 - 20,000 gallon with diesel fuel, AST 8-PREP-2 - 10,000 gallon with Fec-02, AST 8-PREP-3 - 10,000 gallon with diesel fuel, AST 9-LOAD-1  - 1000 gallons with kerosene and AST 10-PREP-1 - 15,000 with diesel fuel.  The condition of the tank was visually inspected for leaks, welds, piping, surface, and freeboard.  The position of the discharge valve was noted to be in the closed position.  All tanks at the D Portal complex are still here and are empty and according to Aaron out of service. (10) A pH Meter Calibration Logbook was available for my inspection.  It was complete with corrected values for calibration.  A 2-point calibration of the pH meter is used.  The Calibration Logbook was complete with dates, times, and all required values including the operator's signature.  A Hach Sension I hand operated pH meter is used by operators to measure the pH and temperature at remote outfalls.  A Great Lakes Instrument with remote probe continuously measure pH and temperature at Outfall 002 and records the results on a Circular Chart Recorder. The probe is calibrated weekly with buffers 7 and 10.  Calibration records were available for my review. (11) None of the buffers used for pH calibration were found expired. (12) A thorough examination of DMRs was conducted.  No errors were reported.  Each was submitted in a timely fashion, signed and dated.  There were no transcription errors. (13)  Aaron Miller, Environmental Coordinator, still does an outstanding job of organizing Mettiki's environmental records.  Required reports and documents were grouped by month for easy inspection.  Mr. Miller had no problem finding any document requested. (14) Although the Mettiki Coal, LLC does not have backup power capabilities, a Sensaphone 400 automatic dialing system alerts Plant personnel during outages and equipment failure. (15) Appendix F of the Emergency Response Plan included a list of equipment available during emergency situations.  The equipment is owned by Preston Contractors. (16) Mettiki Coal LLC subscribes to MSDS Online.  Mettiki maintains a list of polymers and a total of over 750 listed materials.  Employees can print any MSDS from their designated work station. Mr. Miller noted the ability of e-mailing an MSDS to hospitals during emergency situations.  It appears all Special Conditions and Requirements are current and compliant at this time.  Recommend prior to the winter months schedule sumps along road way and adjacent to Belt 34 to be cleaned and also schedule to clean under over land belt line. The pipe line between A Portal area and D Portal area has been reclaimed and stabilized as per the last inspection.

During an internal office review of the permit it was discovered that the operator has not submitted the required monthly tonnage report for the month of June 2014. This report was due on July 25, 2014.  The Operator is in violation of the Annotated Code of Maryland / Environmental Title  ?15-615(a) which states; By the twenty-fifth day of each month, a deep mine operator shall file a monthly progress report with the Secretary on a form furnished by the Secretary. In the report, the operator shall indicate the tonnage of coal removed.  A violation is being issued this date.

At 02:20 AM I received a call from Vindex Energy Safety Manager Hillary Strawser. She stated that an accident occurred at this operation at approximately 12:50 AM involving a D-11 Dozer that went over the highwall. She stated that MSHA had been contacted and that the dozer operator was not seriously injured. Also she stated that a rescue operation involving the local Fire Departments is under way to recover the dozer operator.  I responded to the mine site and found that Fire/Rescue personnel were in the process of rescuing the dozer operator (Dave Bosley) via a scree evacuation operation.  At 04:13 I contacted BOM Director John Carey and advised him of the accident and ongoing rescue operation.  At approximately 04:37 AM the dozer operator was hoisted to the top of the highwall and taken to the ambulance for transport to the Western Maryland Regional Medical Center for evaluation. He was later released after medical staff evaluated his condition.  At 05:26 AM I contacted BOM Inspector Ron Schartiger to assist me with the investigation.  MSHA issued a 103(j) Citation/Order #8060224 which states that this order is being issued to prevent the destruction of any evidence that would assist in the investigation the cause or causes of the accident. It prohibits all activity at the Borden Pit except for the recovery of the victim until MSHA has determined that it is safe to resume normal mining operations in this area.  At 08:17 I contacted BOM Acting Director Al Hooker and briefed him of the situation.  After reviewing the accident seen at daylight, the MSHA Order was modified to allow the operator to implement the "Bulldozer Recovery Plan" dated 8/7/14. All equipment used in rescue operations were released from this order with the exception of the Cat D11 Dozer #048, involved in the accident. Once this dozer is recovered it may be moved to a safe location within the pit where it will remain under order, preventing any work or movement of the dozer until MSHA can inspect the machine.  When Mr. Bosley returned to the mine site after being evaluated at the hospital, MSHA conducted an interview with him. He stated that he thought that he was pushing an access off the shot material down to the Tyson bench.  At the conclusion of our investigation it was determined that the operator was working to close too the highwall edge and had mistaken where he was trying to make access down to the Tyson bench.  This investigation is complete except for the recovery of the Cat D-11 dozer. Vindex Energy Mine Superintendent Rodney Tichinel is to contact this Inspector when the recovery of the D-11 dozer is in its final stages.  The cooperation between Vindex Energy Staff, MSHA and the local Fire/Rescue Departments was excellent. This made for a good outcome of an extremely dangerous rescue operation that resulted no serious injury or loss of life.

On site review of the permit area this date, discussed permit area with Troy and Ted Schwinabart. Reviewed the backfilling area on Increment II and according to Troy there is a dozer designated to backfill on that area everyday. Reviewed Pond 003 area: As per the last inspection, 1) Emergency Spillway is not constructed correct, put 10 feet grass apron on exit of spillway and place durable rock on the spillway as per the approved permit. The 10 feet area for the grass apron has begun, not seeded and mulched, this is scheduled when seeding and mulching occurs on the other disturbance.  Rip rap has been placed in the emergency spillway and is scheduled to be completed.   2) Fix linear crack approximately about half way out the breast of pond.  According to Ted the weather has not cooperated and is scheduled to be completed, it has rained the last 4 out of 5 days.  3) Install 90 degree elbow on discharge pipe.  Elbow is ordered and expected to be in on Thursday of this week.  4) Place 10 feet of rip rap out pond bottom of each entrance channels. Entrance channel for Ditch 3 is completed.  5) Regrade Ditch 3 with a minimum of 18 inch free board as per the approved permit, one portion of the ditch has almost silted in with sediment washed from the rough backfill.  This ditch has been regraded and the 18 inch freeboard is there, but gullies from the backfill are starting to silt in the ditch.  Recommend for the operator to regrade the backfill area and place diversion ditches to prevent this from reoccurring.  Ditch again needs to be regraded and there is a pool of water in the ditch line and it is also silting in, the ditch needs positive drainage to prevent this from happening.  It could be a continuing problem if you don't have positive drainage. Seed and mulch when completed.  6) Ditch on south end of pond, near Increment IV, needs regraded, seeded and mulched.  This hasn't been done, possible it wasn't gotten due to the rains.   As the work is completed grade, seed and mulch any disturbance and also below the pond where the equipment has been trammed.         Reviewed Pond 004 area: As per the last inspection, at the area water is leaving the pit the operator is to remove the material from that area and construct a sump with a rip rap discharge.  This has been completed and looks good.  The silt fence below the disturbance is doing its job by collecting the sediment and coal fines.  The silt fence in areas has sediment and coal fines built up about half way, clean sediment and coal fines from the silt fence and keep the silt fence tight and other maintenance if needed. According to Ted he had explained to the equipment operator and thought it was completed.  It is apparent it wasn't completed, schedule to complete as weather allows.  Also discussed with Ted to repair gullies on the Planting Report 9, on Increment I on the Bakerstown and Harlem Coal Seam areas and the area On Increment II that was just planted last year, that is also on the Bakerstown Coal Seam area.  This needs to be completed by August 18, 2014.

On site review of the permit area this date with Rich Riggins the General Superintendent for the Operator. Little water in pit area. Reviewed Freeport area the operator is mining this date.  Overburden from the Freeport Coal Seam area is being placed in the pit where the spoil seep has been present (see the attached map).  Approximately a month ago the operator graded the area above this pit and place diversion ditches on the spoil and diverted the flow of water from this pit area.  Now the area's drainage is flowing to Perimeter Ditch 2 and not in the pit area.  This has slowed down the flow of the seep considerable.  This seep in the spoil this date is flowing little to none.  Material from the Freeport area is being placed in this pit, at this time in 2 foot lifts and a cover of ganulated limestone placed on top of the material. The backfilling of this pit is continuing with that.  It is a clay like material and appears to be compacting well, which there are no requirements for compaction. The pit area of the Freeport is being pumped, in pit water storage, with a pH of 7 this date. The operator is hauling 30 truck loads, a day, of the granulated limestone to the site.

On site review of the permit area with Rich Riggins for the purpose of inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines. Off site inspection with Jeff Snyder for the purpose of seismagraphing a shot at the residence of Mr. Mark Beachy as a follow up from a complaint filed in June, 2014.  Tri-Star Mining set their Seismograph up at the nearest dwelling to the shot. Jeff Snyder and I set up two Seismographs at the Beachy Residence at 188 Marsh Street, Westernport MD. One was set up along Marsh Street adjacent to Mr. Beachy's home and the second was set up behind Mr. Beachy's home approximately 100' closer to the shot. The shot was set off at 3:53 PM. The readings after the shot were as follows; Tri-Star's ppv = 0.035, 107.5dBL. Maryland Bureau of Mines seismograph #1 along Marsh Street, ppv = 0.04, 106 dBL, Seismograph #2 behind the Beachy Home, ppv = 0.04, 107.5 dBL.  Mr. Beachy was notified of the readings but was still upset over the outcome of the seismograph results. All Seismograph reports for SM-00-436 for the month of August 2014 will be sent to this inspector at the Maryland Bureau of Mines office for review.  After a review of the seismograph report, Tri-Star is in compliance with PPV at .035 and a dB reading of 107.5.  No other issues noted.  Any questions, please call this inspector at (301) 697-0344

On 6/9/14, The Bureau of Mines received a complaint from Mr. Mark Beachy, one of the surface owners of SM-00-436. Mr. Beachy was irate and is demanding that all mining on his property cease, all backfilling is to be completed, all equipment, fuel tanks and haul roads to be removed within 30 days. Mr. Beachy also stated that the next time his house "rattles" from a shot; he will be calling in another complaint. Bureau of Mines Compliance and Enforcement Supervisor, Tom Murray took the complaint.  On 6/10/14, Bureau of Mines Lead Inspector, Ralph Mongold called Mr. Beachy to address his complaint, Mr. Beachy was very adamant about having Tri-Star Mining removed from his property. In order to assist in defusing the situation and at Mr. Beachy's request, Bureau of Mines Director, John Carey called Mr. Beachy and received the same responses that were given to Tom Murray and Ralph Mongold.           Surface Mine SM-00-436 is active and currently in compliance with the Maryland Bureau of Mines. All mining on Mr. Beachy's property is complete and only backfilling, re-grading and planting remain. The open pit will remain until Tri-Star Mining mines through the neighboring SM- 01-440 as a Contract Miner under G&S Coal. To date, Tri-Star has been working five to six days per week for four continuous weeks to complete as much backfilling and reclamation work as possible on the Beachy property. Albeit against Mr. Beachy's wishes, Tri-Star Mining does not have to remove fuel tanks, haul roads or equipment until final reclamation is achieved as per the approved Coal Mine Permit. This was a follow up inspection to last month's inspection.   Sediment and drainage controls were functioning properly. On this date Pond #1 was discharging a 7.0 pH, 2200 specific conductance, 6.0 Fe @ 65 degrees F.   This ongoing investigation into the iron discharge shows the iron levels in the discharge are up and down. On this date the flowing pit water showed iron levels of 10. This may be due to ongoing backfilling operations or the material handling. However, the operator is reminded that the effluent limits of their general discharge permit for iron are a maximum daily limit of 6 and an average monthly limit of 3. I discussed this with Ted and Troy and suggested that they install some temporary check dams where the water drains out the pit to help with retention time to allow the iron to precipitate before being discharged. They agreed and also stated that they are adding additional lime and ash material to the backfill and pit floor. Also the operator has recently cleaned the pond. In order to truck the material out the emergency spillway was disturbed.   Before my next inspection re-establish the rock rip-rap material in the emergency spillway in order to avoid a violation. The approved design calls for the spillway to be 24' wide with 2:1 side slopes. The rip-rap material must be good durable material and the size of the material is to be a D-50 of 15" and D-min. of 9" and a D-max of 18".   On this date a dozer was working on the backfill. The operator is reminded to continue backfilling 40 hrs. /week until the site is contemporaneous.  No blasting at this site during the last quarter.

On site review of the permit area with Rich Riggins, Nick Riggins, Austin Belcher, John Carey, Al Hooker, Michelle Arrington, Mark Hagas and Tom Murray for the purpose of inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  A seep of iron laden water was identified close to the location of the reclaimed Pond #7. At the time of this inspection, the pH was field tested at 6.5 and it is apparent that the iron levels are elevated. A Hach Field Test Kit was used and it revealed an iron content of greater than 10 ppm. Due to the elevated iron levels and the ph at 6.5, the iron is dropping out and staining the area. After talking with the previous inspector, Tom Murray, I was informed of an old deep mine entry from an abandoned deep mine workings in this general area. The annual maps for this permit also show the abandoned mine as well as pre-law surface mines in the general vicinity of the seep. Routine water sampling and stream monitoring reveals that there has been no impact on the receiving streams at this time. Pre-mining water samples were taken by Vindex Energy at location MK4. This sample location will be GPS located and compared to the GPS coordinates of the current seep to compare the proximities of the two locations. Vindex Energy has requested to monitor the seep and take samples of the seep as well as the receiving stream, both above and below the mixing zone. The sampling will be done periodically and all documentation will be forwarded on the Bureau of Mines. At such time, the Bureau will determine if Vindex Energy is responsible for the seep and if a NOVO is warranted. Vindex Energy will also be performing water sample "Finger Printing" of the current seep and comparing it to the seeps of pre-law deep mine workings that are throughout the area.           Vindex Energy has been taking samples and analyzing the surface and ground water of the area around the seep. Also, Vindex Energy has been researching the old pre-law mine maps of the area to try and determine the source. Today's meeting was to allow the Permitting Section of the BOM to see the seep first hand and to assist in the assessment of the seep and its origin. Vindex Energy will provide the BOM with the lab results and sampling data of all water samples taken. The site is active today with backfilling in progress and preparations are being made for seeding and mulching of several areas of the permit. On this date a complaint was received from Jeremy Jacobs. Mr. Jacobs was complaining about dust coming from the coal trucks as they go by his residence.  I went to the site and inspected the entrance for tracking issues. Some minor tracking was coming from the job site. I contacted Tri-Star Mining General Mine Foreman Ray Tighe and advised him to spread additional clean stone to the job entrance. While I was on site, a loader came and spread additional clean stone as requested.  I spoke to Mr. Jacobs about his complaint and advised him that I was on site and that they were spreading clean stone on the entrance to control any tracking issues. He said he was also concerned about the trucks speeding on this narrow county road. On site review of the permit area with Rich Riggins, Nick Riggins, Austin Belcher, John Carey and Tom Murray for the purpose of inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  A seep of iron laden water was identified close to the location of the reclaimed Pond #7. At the time of this inspection, the pH was field tested at 6.5 and it is apparent that the iron levels are elevated. A Hach Field Test Kit was used and it revealed an iron content of greater than 10 ppm. Due to the elevated iron levels and the ph at 6.5, the iron is dropping out and staining the area. After talking with the previous inspector, Tom Murray, I was informed of an old deep mine entry from an abandoned deep mine workings in this general area. The annual maps for this permit also show the abandoned mine as well as pre-law surface mines in the general vicinity of the seep. Routine water sampling and stream monitoring reveals that there has been no impact on the receiving streams at this time. Pre-mining water samples were taken by Vindex Energy at location MK4. This sample location will be GPS located and compared to the GPS coordinates of the current seep to compare the proximities of the two locations. Vindex Energy has requested to monitor the seep and take samples of the seep as well as the receiving stream, both above and below the mixing zone. The sampling will be done periodically and all documentation will be forwarded on the Bureau of Mines. At such time, the Bureau will determine if Vindex Energy is responsible for the seep and if a NOVO is warranted. Vindex Energy will also be performing water sample "Finger Printing" of the current seep and comparing it to the seeps of pre-law deep mine workings that are throughout the area.  Any questions regarding this inspection, please contact this inspector at (301)697-0344.

The pit cleanings need to be kept off the bottom and capped with alkaline material. Also, the approved mining plan shows that potentially toxic material is located approximately 20- 28 feet above the horizon of the Lower Bakerstown coal seam. This material also needs to be kept up off the pit floor and covered with the immediate roof material overlying the Lower Bakerstown coal seam which contains net alkalinity values.
