On 3/19/2014 a complaint from Mr. Jerry Zembower concerning fugitive dust was received. I spoke to Mr. Zembower on this date and he stated that every morning he has to run his wipers on his vehicle to clear the dust off the windshield and that his house is covered with dust from the Cabin Run strip job.   During this inspection the main haulroad and the interior haul roads were being watered and were in compliance. I spoke to John Bennett, the mine foreman, about trying to suppress the fugitive dust created during blasting operations. This could possibly be done with a water cannon after the "All Clear Signal" is given. They are going to try to do this. The company appears to be making every effort to minimize fugitive dust and be in compliance.   The upper coal processing area perimeter control ditch needs to be cleaned. Coal fines from the upper and lower coal processing area need to be controlled with interior sumps before reaching Pond #2.   Drainage control ditches are functioning properly. Pond #1 was not discharging. Standing water in the pond field tested an 8.0 pH. Pond #2 was dry. Pond #3 was discharging a 7.0 pH, 220 specific conductance @ 36 degrees F. Pond #4 was not discharging. Standing water in this structure field tested a 7.4 pH. Water monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.   The requested information to estimate the existing pit volume was submitted to the BOM for review.  Blasting records are on file at the mine office and up to date.

On site inspection of the deep mine surface area today with ARJ site Engineer Kevin Clark.  During an office review of this permit it was discovered that the Annual Report and Pond Certifications were not submitted as required under the Annotated Code of Maryland / Environment Title 15-615 which states that an annual report shall be furnished to the Secretary not later than February 25 if each year for the preceding year covering facts the Secretary may require regarding the production and condition of the operation during the calendar year preceding. The operator also shall update the information on the maps previously supplied with the permit application. The Pond Certifications are required in COMAR 26.20.21.09 C and states that an impoundment shall be inspected at least annually by a professional engineer or other qualified specialist under the direction of the professional engineer until removal of the impoundment or release of the performance bond.  As of this date the Annual Report and Pond Certifications have not been submitted to the Bureau therefore Violation (1 of 2) DM111-140310-NOV will be issued.  Also on this date the emergency spillway on Pond #1 was blocked with pond cleanings and has not been cleaned as directed on my last inspection report.  As per COMAR 26.20.21.08 H (2) Impoundments shall be routinely maintained during the mining operations in the following areas: (2) Ditches and spillways shall be cleaned; therefore Violation (2 of 2) DM111-140310-NOV will be issue.  You are hereby ordered to submit the Annual Report and Pond Certifications and to clean, repair and/or replace the rip-rap material as per the approved pond "as build" within 7 days. If you have any questions contact this Inspector.   Pond #1 was discharging an 8.2 pH, 480 specific conductance @ 36 degrees F.  This deep mine site was producing coal on two sections today.  Coal is being processed and loaded onto trucks for shipment.
No discharge today. Ponds are covered with ice and snow. Mining in progress.  No problems observed.

Inspection conducted with Tri-Star Mining General Mine Foreman Ray Tighe.  The contract operator Tri-Star Mining, was actively mining the Franklin coal seams today.  On 2/18/13 the Allegany Roads Dept. complained to Kerry Beener and also called G&S Coal and complained about water running out the haulroad and onto the county road. Ray Tighe called me and informed me about the complaint.  On this date I inspected the site and found that the entire drainage control system is covered with heavy snow and has been thawing due to warmer temperatures. Melting snow can be expected to leave the site at different locations until the drainage control facilities thaw. Almost all the properties alone this county road show signs of melting snow and water running out onto the county road. In fact, the county road side ditch is full of heavy wet snow and cannot function because of it. These conditions are to be expected during this type of weather condition.  Tri-Star has made the extra effort and put in some additional drainage breaks on the haulroad. During this investigation water was not running out the haulroad and onto the county road. No further investigation is needed for this complaint.  No problems were observed during this inspection.

Ron Schartiger will be inspecting the bore hole so any questions on the bore hole or mine facility contact Ron @ 301-697-0344 or Al Hooker @ 301-689-1446. No discharge today.  The ponds are iced over.  Mining in progress on the last cuts on this permit.  DMR's are current and appear in good  order. We recently received blasting complaints from shots put off on the 6th and the 10th of this month. Both shots were within permit limits.  Virginia Brumage requested a seismograph be set up at her residence and a phone call prior to the next blast.  David Hartman was not satisfied with my explanation of blasting procedure and the Bureau of Mines in general and requested to see John Carey.  He was advised to call John's voice mail with his request.
This is an AML reclamation project managed by the  Bureau of Mines.  No discharge today. The pond is ice covered. Llittle change on site since last inspection.

On site was Rich Riggins the General Superintendent for the Operator, Nick Riggins the Environmental Technician and Wayne's Water and Well Company drilling a new well for MW-1. This well has been completed and they are scheduled to modify the old MW-1 well tomorrow as per the instructions from Al Hooker the Chief of Permitting for the Bureau of Mines.

This surface coal mine site was actively conducting mining operations today.  The main haulroad was thawing and muddy and starting to track out onto the county road. I spoke to John, the site Foreman, and ask them to correct the problem. Before I left the site, the haulroad was scraped with a grader and clean stone was being applied to it.  The rip-rap material on the entrance channel & emergency spillway of Pond #1 has been replaced with good sandstone material. The rills & gullies at and above Pond #1 will be fixed when the winter weather breaks and as weather permits.  Coal was being processed and loaded onto trucks for shipment.

This site has a "Temporary Cessation of Mining Activities" good until 6/30/14.  Drainage and sediment control facilities are snow & ices covered but appear to be functioning properly. The ponds were frozen and snow covered with no discharge on this date. Water monitoring reports are being submitted on time with no violations noted.  No problems or concerns were observed during this inspection.
Discharge from outfall # 003 today has a pH of 6.8, 980 Us at 59  F .  No discharge from outfall # 002. DMR's are current and appear in good order.  Heavy rainfall last night.
On site review of the permit area with Gary Bean the Foreman for the Operator. Backfilling is being conducted this date. No problems observed this date.

The contract operator Tri-Star Mining, was actively mining the Franklin coal seams today.  No problems were observed during this inspection.

This inspection was conducted with Tri-Star Mining General Mine Foreman Ray Tighe. This surface coal mine site was active today.  Rock trucks are still hauling material to complete the valley fill area.  Seismograph readings for blasting in the southern pit are being taken at the Stafford residence.  Overburden is being removed from the Morantown and Little Pittsburgh coal seams in the southern pit.  The haulroad was in satisfactory condition.

On site review of the permit area this date after the Bureau had mailed a letter to Austin Belcher, the Environmental Coordinator about the quality of MW-1 well.  On site was Rich Riggins the General Superintendent for the Operator, Nick Riggins the Environmental Technician and Austin Belcher the Environmental Coordinator and Tom Jones the Manager of Engineering for the Operator and this inspector. This meeting was on site and continued to the Bureau of Mines Office with John Carey the Director of the Bureau of Mines and Al Hooker the Chief of Permitting and Mark Hajas and Jeff Snyder of the Permitting Section along with Tom Jones and Rich Riggins. Reviewed the MW-1 location and surrounding areas while on site. Reviewed the pit areas, highwalls and treatment of the pit water.  Pumping the pit water to Pond 002 this date. According to Tom Jones the Operator will submit a plan immediately and he has already contacted a driller to construct another well as per the meeting in the Bureau's Office.

On site review today for inspection and enforcement for the Maryland Bureau of Mines.  Permit site is snow covered. This permit is in Inactive Status. Pond #1 has 2" to 3" of water but is frozen over. Road maintenance will need to be scheduled for the spring.  No problems or issues were observed.
